questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is heat stable and obtained from bacteria?
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase is used in PCR. It is heat stable and is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. It lacks a proofreading activity.

DNA synthesis in PCR is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase. It is purified from thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA.

The technique of PCR:

Denaturation- sample DNA strands are separated by heating at 95℃ for 15 seconds to 2 minutes.

Annealing- the primers, added in vast excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically 50–75°C). The primers hybridize with their complementary single-stranded DNA.

Extension- each strand is copied by a Taq polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four nucleotides (dNTPs) at 72℃.

The image given below shows the steps involved in PCR.


The image given below shows the resources required for PCR:


Other options:

Option A: DNA polymerase III is involved in the replication. This enzyme binds to template DNA to synthesize DNA in the 5' to 3' direction at the replication fork.

Option B: Endonuclease is involved in the replication. The mismatched base during replication is identified and removed by the endonuclease activity.

Option D: DNA gyrase is involved in the replication. It unwinds the DNA and relieves supercoils during replication. They act on the closed circular DNA of bacteria.

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given in the figure ?

choices.text: Refine the power and axis of cylindrical lens
Measure the degree of heterophoria or heterotropia in cases of torsional diplopia

questions.solution:
The above instrument is a Maddox rod. It is used to measure the degree of heterophoria or heterotropia in cases of torsional diplopia.

Maddox Rod Test:

  • It involves the use of a Maddox rod and the Maddox tangent scale.
  • It uses a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image.
  • A patient is asked to fix on a point light 6 meters away.
  • The optical properties of the cylinders cause the streak of light to be situated 90° to the orientation of the parallel cylinders.
  • Because fusion is precluded by the Maddox rod, heterophorias, and heterotopias cannot be differentiated.
  • The Maddox rod can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo-deviations.

Interpretation of the Test:

  • To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction.
  • The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical line with the left eye and white light with the right eye.
  • If the light superimposes the line, orthophoria is present.
  • If the light is on the left side of the line, it is an exo-deviation; and if the light was on the right side of the line, an esodeviation would be present.

Orthophoria: perfect ocular alignment in the absence of any stimulus for fusion

Hypophoria: downward imbalance

Hyperphoria: upward imbalance

Exophoria: outward imbalance

Esophoria: small inward imbalance

In the following image, the interpretation of the result is based on how the patient visualizes it. It would appear to be crossed to the patient. Pictorial representation of the eyes are as seen by the examiner. Imagine you are looking through a Maddox rod over your left and right eyes while interpreting the images.

questions.text: Tryptophan loading test is done to detect deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The tryptophan load test is done to detect the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6).

In the catabolism of tryptophan through the kynurenine anthranilate pathway, the enzyme kynureninase requires pyridoxal phosphate as a coenzyme for converting  3-OH Kynurenine to further sequential compounds in tryptophan catabolism. In pyridoxol phospahate deficiency, 3-OH Kynurenine is converted to xanthurenic acid, which is excreted in the urine.

Hence, to detect B6 deficiency, tryptophan is given and xanthurenic acid is tested in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about miRNA?

choices.text: DICER is involved in the processing of miRNA

questions.solution:
The inhibition is done at the level of translation.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/ siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequence in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Such misregulation is thought to have a causal role in the pathogenesis of such cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic (referred to as oncomiRs) and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumour-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.

questions.text: 1 Lakh students took the Grand Test conducted by marrow. The mean score was 628 with a standard deviation of 18. Assuming a normal distribution, how many students scored more than 664?
questions.solution:
2500 students scored more than 664 marks. 

664 is 2 standard deviations above the mean. 95% of the students fall between -2 to +2 and only 5% lie below -2 or above +2. Here, 95% of the students (95% of 1 lakh = 95000) lie between 592 and 664. 5000 lie below 592 or above 664. Hence, the number of students who scored more than 664 is 5000/2 = 2500.

questions.text: The given image shows an insulin regimen, in this regimen insulin is given by _____ route.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the insulin levels produced by using an insulin pump. In an insulin pump, insulin is delivered by subcutaneous route.


The given image can be interpreted as insulin levels produced by an insulin pump by the following features:

  • There is continuous basal coverage of insulin as seen in the image, mimicking a normal human pancreas
  • Also, at the time of meals, it gives bolus spikes to meet the anticipated increase in glucose levels

The image shows an insulin regimen consisting of a twice-daily injection of NPH insulin (yellow line) providing basal insulin coverage and regular insulin (blue dashed line) or an insulin analogue (glulisine, aspart and lispro in red) providing mealtime insulin coverage.

Duration of NPH insulin is around 10-16 hours, insulin degludec is 24-42 hours, regular insulin is 4-6 hours and insulin glulisine is around 3-4 hours.

The above image shows multiple-component insulin regimen consisting of long-acting insulin (degludec, detemir, or glargine), which are denoted by green color to provide basal insulin coverage and three shots of short-acting insulin (glulisine, lispro, or insulin aspart), indicated in red color, to provide glycemic coverage for each meal.

questions.text: The following images show:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Jersey finger and baseball finger.

  • Jersey finger - It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of distal phalanx with the ring finger most commonly involved.
  • Baseball finger: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon of the little finger or thumb when the collision with a hard object (a ball) forces it to flex past its normal range of motion.

 

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, who had attended his retirement party, came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a picture similar to the one given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). 

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Clinical features

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe edema- the whole retina looks white in color
  • Marked attenuation of arteries - thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein - cattle-track appearance

Fundoscopy may also show Hollenhorst plaque. Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came with complaints of a sudden decreased vision in both eyes and pain while moving his eyeballs. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart.  Fundus examination showed normal discs and vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. The normal optic disc is an important pointer toward retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis is of three types, based on the appearance of optic disc on fundoscopy:

  • Retrobulbar neuritis - Normal optic disc because optic nerve head is not involved.
  • Papillitis - Hyperemic and edematous disc with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages.
  • Neuroretinitis - Macular star appearance due to involvement of nerve fiber layer (NFL)

The clinical features of retrobulbar neuritis include sudden painful vision loss, decreased color contrast sensitivity, Marcus Gunn pupil and pain on movement of eyeballs.

Demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis are the most common cause of retrobulbar neuritis.

Steroids are the mainstay of treatment for such demyelinating causes.

Option A: Eale's disease is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Due to this, the fundoscopic findings will not be normal. It is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular proteins. This causes periphlebitis leading to hemorrhages.

Option B: Papilloedema is swelling of the optic nerve head due to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Here also the optic disc would not be normal. The patient will have symptoms of raised ICP such as headache, nausea, deterioration of consciousness, etc.

Option D: Papillitis will have an abnormal optic disc as described above.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about pleomorphic adenoma.

choices.text: It has true capsule bound anteriorly
It is one of the radioresistant  tumors
involves facial nerve causing facial palsy

questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma is one of the radioresistant tumors. It is the most common tumor of the parotid gland. Most commonly, they arise from the superficial lobe, and all tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present (option A)
  • Potentially malignant(option D)
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Slowly growing, painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement (option C)
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presented jaundice and pruritus. Mildly elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase and γ-glutamyl transpeptidase were detected. The titer of anti-mitochondrial M2 anti-body was elevated. Histopathology is suggestive of a cirrhotic liver. Which of the following conditions is unlikely to be seen in association with this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis. Ulcerative colitis is not seen in association with primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).

PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1.

Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.

Histology:

  • Florid duct lesion: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with or without granulomas centered around the bile duct (diagnostic)
  • Mallory–Denk bodies

 Associated conditions in PBC:

  • Sjogren syndrome
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  • CREST syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Celiac disease

Inflammatory bowel disorders (ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease) is seen in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

  • Color; body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate; 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition. Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation.

Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for false positive Apgar score are:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: HbS causes sickling because it is significantly different from HbA in which of the following aspects?
questions.solution:
HbS is less soluble than HbA.

In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine at the 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscous gel. This causes a change in solubility of the hemoglobin.

The major pathologic manifestations are chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage. They can be attributed to this impaired solubility and polymerization of HbS.

questions.text: A man was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT-scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?
questions.solution:
The third part of the axillary artery lies lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle. Injury in this part causes decreased blood supply in all branches of the third part of the axillary artery. The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, and is, therefore, the least likely to be affected.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of the 1st rib to the lower border of teres major, from where it continues as the brachial artery.

Pectoralis minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to, and lateral/distal to the muscle).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding parenteral administration of alteplase?

choices.text: Haemorrhage is a major toxicity, reversed by tranexamic acid

questions.solution:
Alteplase does not increase the formation of plasminogen but it activates plasminogen, resulting in the increased formation of plasmin.

All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted by administration of antifibrinolytics, such as ε-aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid.

It does not cause any change in platelet count.

Its efficacy is equivalent to that of streptokinase, but alteplase has the advantage of activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) rapidly.

questions.text: You are a doctor in a village. A 1 yr old child presents with fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, he is calm, with a respiratory rate of 51 breaths/min. Stridor is present. According to IMNCI (Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses), how is he classified?
questions.solution:
This child is classified as having a very severe disease/severe pneumonia. 

Signs of very severe disease are:

  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Not able to drink
  • Convulsions
  • Abnormally sleepy or difficult to wake
  • Severe malnutrition.

In any of these cases, an urgent referral is very important.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented to the casualty in an unconscious state. His blood sugars were high, the ABG(Arterial blood gas) analysis showed metabolic acidosis, and urine tests were positive for ketone bodies. The ketone bodies were not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme:
questions.solution:
Ketone bodies are not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

The above clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis characterized by excess production of ketone bodies. The liver cannot utilize the ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase (also called succinyl CoA acetoacetyl CoA transferase).

Ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver mitochondria (by ketogenesis) and transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues. Here they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate (the most predominant ketone body) is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

When higher than normal ketone bodies are present in the blood or urine, it is called ketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The metabolism of free fatty acids to produce ketone bodies is exaggerated in pathologic states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, thus causing ketosis. The continued buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the alkali reserve, causing ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of sudden painless loss of vision as if a curtain fell before his eyes. He also experiences flashes of light. On examination, pigments are found on the anterior vitreous like tobacco dusted over the posterior wall of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis from the clinical scenario is retinal detachment.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). Retinal detachment is classified into the following depending upon the fluid accumulation:

  • Rhegmatogenous
  • Tractional
  • Exudative

Risk factors include myopia, previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia, a family history of retinal detachment, and trauma.

Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, flashes of light or photopsia, floaters in the eye, and curtains in the field of vision.

Examination findings will reveal:

  • Normal or slightly low intraocular pressure
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (relative afferent pupillary defect)
  • Altered red reflex on the distant direct ophthalmoscope
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy may show grey reflex of the freshly detached retina or breaks in the retina 
  • Vitreous pigments on the anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign)
  • Shifting fluid sign- Change in the position of the detached area with a change in gravity is the hallmark of exudative retinal detachment.

Management of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment includes sealing of retinal breaks, reducing the vitreous traction on the retina, and flattening of the retina by draining the subretinal fluid. Scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and pars plana vitrectomy can help in maintaining the chorioretinal apposition. 

Treating the cause helps in exudative retinal detachment. Enucleation can be done if intranuclear tumors are present.

Other options:

Option A- Stargardt disease is the most common type of macular dystrophy. It presents as decreased vision in the first or second decade of life. Fundus examination will show beaten bronze or snail-slime reflex in the macular area.

Option B- Macular edema is the collection of fluid in the macula. It occurs due to the leakage from dilated capillaries. Slit lamp examination will show loss of the foveal reflex and thickening at or around the macula. Fluorescein angiography is used to identify the areas of leakage.

Option C- Eales disease is the inflammation of peripheral retinal veins leading to recurrent retinal hemorrhages. Patients will have a sudden painless loss of vision and floaters. The examination will show hemorrhage and vascularisation of the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the triad of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.solution:
The triad of PNH includes

  • Hemolysis
  • Pancytopenia
  • Venous thrombosis 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG).

These cells lack the ability to synthesize proteins that limit the activity of complement. As a result, they are sensitive to lysis by the complement C5b-C9 membrane attack complex.

PNH presents with:

  • Hematuria- classic presentation
  • Anemia- associated with neutropenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Recurrent attacks of severe abdominal pain- related to thrombosis in abdominal veins, or NO depletion due to intravascular hemolysis
  • Acute hepatomegaly and ascites (Budd–Chiari syndrome)- when thrombosis affects the hepatic vein

questions.solution:
A child presenting with a sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, grey-white discharged covered tonsils and gram stain showing gram-positive rods with clubbed ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheria is not chromosome encoded, it is phage-encoded (tox gene). 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation responsible for protein synthesis and the iron level regulates the toxin production.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxaemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).

questions.text: Diagnose the condition based on the flow cytometry:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the flow cytometry is B ALL.

In flow cytometry, the cells show markers such as intracellular tdt, CD 22, CD 19, CD 10. Tdt represents that the cells are blasts, CD 10, 19, 22 represent that cells are B cells.

Flow cytometry can rapidly and quantitatively measure several individual cell characteristics but is mainly used to identify cellular antigens expressed by liquid tumours such as  B- and T-cell lymphomas and leukaemias, as well as myeloid neoplasms.

An advantage of flow cytometry over immunohistochemistry is that multiple antigens can be assessed simultaneously on individual cells using combinations of specific antibodies linked to different fluorescent dyes.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she presented with seizures, aphasia, and hemiparesis. Which of the following investigations is useful to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis. This condition can be diagnosed using MR venography.

Cortical vein thrombosis :    

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Clinical presentation is highly variable. Headache is the most common symptom. Motor or sensory deficits may be seen. Seizures along with focal deficits in the absence of raised intracranial pressure are suggestive of cortical venous thrombosis. Brain MRI with MR venography is a sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition.

questions.text: Regarding the disposal of refuse, which of the following is a controlled tipping method?
questions.solution:
Ramp method is a type of controlled tipping method. 

Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping:

  1. The trench method
  2. The ramp method
  3. The area method

Other methods of refuse disposal:

  • Dumping: Refuse is dumped into low lying areas by throwing it in open space.
  • Incineration: It is the method of choice of disposal by burning when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting:
    • This is a method of combined disposal of refuse and sludge.
    • Compost has manorial value for soil.
    • It includes 2 methods:
      • Bangalore method - Anaerobic composting
      • Indore method - Aerobic mechanical composting
  • Manure pits: Commonly used in rural areas in India.
  • Burial: Suitable for small camps.

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate is 98 beats/minute, no respirations are noted. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A term neonate who remains apnoeic despite stimulation should be given positive pressure ventilation by a bag and mask. 
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic comes to you with a rash over the intertriginous areas, which is more pronounced over his groin.  Wood's lamp examination shows coral pink fluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coral pink fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is characteristic of erythrasma.

Erythrasma is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It is common in diabetics and immunodeficient patients and is associated with obesity, sweating and poor hygiene.

Coral pink fluorescence is due to the production of coproporphyrin III by the bacterium.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset neurological deficits. On examination, he is found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the left side of the face and right side of the body. He also has dysphagia with a deviation of the uvula to the right. Which blood vessel is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome due to the involvement of a left-sided artery. Hence, the blood vessel most likely to be affected in this patient is the left vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, occurs most commonly due to the occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible for the remaining cases.

The structures affected in lateral medullary syndrome include:

  • Tract and nucleus of V cranial nerve: impaired sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves: ipsilateral paralysis of the palate (dysphagia), vocal cord (hoarseness), diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius: ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus: nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract: ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract: ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

questions.text: A 32yr old male is breathless due to a penetrating chest injury. A diagnosis of pneumothorax is made. His current intrapleural pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure. Which of the following is true regarding the intrapleural pressure of his healthy, pre-injury state?

choices.text: Positive during both inspiration and expiration
Negative during both inspiration and expiration
Positive during inspiration and negative during expiration
Negative during inspiration and positive during expiration

questions.solution:
In healthy individuals, intrapleural pressure is negative during both inspiration and expiration.

It is subatmospheric because two opposing elastic forces pull on the intrapleural space. The lungs, with their elastic properties, tend to collapse, and the chest wall, with its elastic properties, tends to spring out. When these two opposing forces pull on the intrapleural space, a negative pressure, or vacuum, is created. This leads to continuous suction of excess fluid into the lymphatic channels.

In the case of pneumothorax - Intrapleural pressure suddenly becomes equal to atmospheric pressure; thus instead of its normal negative value, intrapleural pressure becomes zero. Hence lungs collapse and the chest wall springs out.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who lost his wife 2 months back was brought to the OPD. He complains of feeling low whenever he thinks of his wife and has lost interest in daily activities. He does not have any suicidal ideations and experiences moments where he is motivated to move on. He mentioned that he had heard his wife's voice once while alone at home. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario described here, after the loss of a loved one, is a normal grief reaction. This reaction also occurs with other losses, such as the loss of a body part, or, for younger people with a miscarriage or abortion.

Normal grief or bereavement begins immediately or a few months after the loss of a loved one. It is characterized initially by shock and denial. The signs and symptoms include feeling low, constant thoughts about the deceased, crying, irritability, and difficulties with sleep and concentration. However, the symptoms are not as pervasive as in depression. The patient's motivation to move on also points in favor of normal grief. The functional impairment is mild.

Transient hallucinations related to the deceased person (hearing the voice of the deceased occasionally) occur in certain cases of normal grief reaction and are not considered psychosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Psychotic depression is characterized by the presence of delusions and/or hallucinations along with the symptoms of depression. It reflects a poor prognosis

Option C: Delusional disorder - Delusions are false beliefs, that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. This is the most common manifestation of delusional disorders. In this scenario, the husband is aware of the fact that his wife is dead.

Option D: Schizophrenia is defined by the presence of psychosis (hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized speech) for more than 6 months. Mood symptoms are absent or present for only brief periods. 

The following pearl differentiates between features of normal grief and depression.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with fever, diarrhea, malaise, and knee pain. Whipple's disease is suspected and a biopsy is taken which shows infiltration of infected tissue by large numbers of foamy macrophages, having inclusions which are positive with which of the following stains?
questions.solution:
The cause of Whipple disease is a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei. The macrophages stain positive with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS).

The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

In Whipple disease, bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, the brain, and other sites. The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhoea, weight loss, and arthralgia.

questions.text: With respect to the Factories Act, which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Per capita space - At least 500 cu.ft/person
Hours of work for adults - Should not be more than 9 hours a day
Age of employment - Should be at least 16 years of age to be employed
Leave with wages - Weekly holidays + 1 day for every 20 days of work for adults

questions.solution:
The Factories Act states that children of age <14 years (not 16 years) cannot be employed. Adolescents between 15–18 years can be employed only in certain industries and can work between 6 AM–7 PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in his thigh. Radiographs show a radiolucent center and surrounding irregular bone formation. CT shows a well-circumscribed mass within muscle with areas of bright calcification. A diagnosis of myositis ossificans is made. The most likely pathological mechanism associated with this is:

choices.text: High levels of prostaglandins within the nidus causing local inflammation
Production of osteoid matrix by the malignant cells
Metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation
Inflammation, bone necrosis and reactive new bone formation

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described here is of myositis ossificans and the pathology associated is metaplasia of fibroblast and bone formation.

Myositis ossificans is a reactive lesion occurring in the soft tissues. It is characterized by fibrous, osseous, and cartilaginous proliferation of the subperiosteal hematoma. This is later followed by metaplastic changes.

High levels of prostaglandin E2 and prostacyclin within the nidus causing local inflammation and vasodilation is seen in osteoid osteoma.

Production of an osteoid matrix by the malignant cells is seen in osteosarcoma.

Inflammation, suppuration, bone necrosis, reactive new bone formation and ultimately, resolution and healing are seen in osteomyelitis.

questions.text: After crowning was established in a patient in labor, the obstetrician uses the instrument shown below to give a liberal episiotomy. By doing so, what grade of perineal injury is the obstetrician iatrogenically inflicting?
questions.solution:
The image shows an episiotomy scissor, which can be identified by its angulation. It is used to perform an episiotomy. During episiotomy, the obstetrician iatrogenically induces a second-degree perineal tear.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear that involves the perineal muscles but spares the anal sphincter. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

Timely episiotomy prevents third and fourth-degree perineal tears, which affect the anal sphincter.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles
  • Fascia covering the muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Episiotomies are either midline or mediolateral:

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical Repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with a history of cough for the past 3 months, which has been associated with hemoptysis for the past 2 days. Further evaluation reveals an M. tuberculosis infection resistant to Rifampicin and Isoniazid but sensitive to fluroquinolone and second line injectables. Which of the following is true regarding the intensive phase of treatment that this patient would require?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin and Isoniazid resistance suggests that the patient has MDR TB (multidrug-resistant). The treatment of MDR TB - the shorter MDR TB regimen uses 7 drugs for 4-6 months (intensive phase) followed by 4 drugs for 5 months (continuation phase).

Among the two regimens for MDR TB treatment, the shorter MDR TB regimen is used for this patient as he/she does not have any exclusion criteria for the same.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure, a person is positioned in such a way that the X-ray beam comes from a 30-degree cephalocaudal angle as shown in the image given below. The X-ray view shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The X-ray view shown in the image is Schuller’s view.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of the skull. The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head and is at an angle of 30° to the radiographic plate. The key area seen in this view is the antrum and upper part of the attic. This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones. The radiograph for each mastoid is taken separately.

Other options:

Option A: Law’s view: the patient lies in such a way that the sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film and the X-ray beam is projected 15° cephalocaudal, a lateral mastoid air cells view without overlap of the opposite side. The below image shows Law’s view.

Option C: Towne’s view: angled anteroposterior view used to demonstrate the occipital bone, foramen magnum, dorsum sellae, and petrous ridges.

Option D: Caldwell's view (or occipitofrontal view) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 20° to orbitomeatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

questions.text: According to various types of thyroplasty, as described by Isshiki, type II thyroplasty refers to:

questions.text: Baclofen is a:
questions.solution:
Baclofen is a GABAB receptor agonist.

Baclofen is a centrally acting muscle relaxant. It is an analog of the inhibitory transmitter GABA and acts as a selective GABAB receptor agonist. It also acts at the spinal cord where it decreases excitatory transmitter release of excitatory neurotransmitter release.

Baclofen is used for the treatment of spasticity in multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, spinal injuries, and flexor spasm. In these conditions, baclofen is the preferred drug for symptomatic relief.

It can also be administered intrathecally around the spinal cord through a catheter placed surgically.

Side effects of baclofen include drowsiness, mental confusion, weakness, and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Nm receptor antagonism is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants. The drugs in this class include pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium, mivacurium, etc.

Option B: D2 receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of bromocriptine. It is used for the treatment of prolactinoma and Parkinson's disease.

Option D: α2 adrenergic receptor agonist is the mechanism of action of clonidine. It is used for the treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the hospital following RTA.  Chest X-ray reveals fracture as shown by the arrow. The long bone fractured in the X-Ray is of which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Given X-Ray shows the fracture of clavicle. Clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.

Long bones are classified as follows:

  • Typical long bones (see figure) have an elongated shaft (diaphysis) and two expanded ends (epiphysis). The shaft has a central medullary cavity and a nutrient foramen directed away from the growing end. E.g., humerus, ulna, radius, femur, tibia, and fibula.
  • Miniature long bones contain only one epiphysis. E.g., metacarpals, metatarsals, and phalanges.
  • Modified long bones have a modified shaft or ends, and no medullary cavity. E.g., clavicle.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 1st trimester presents with genital prolapse. On examination, the cervix visible outside the introitus is replaced into the vagina and held in place by a ring pessary. What is the ideal time to remove the pessary?

choices.text: At the end of her 1st trimester

questions.solution:
Genital prolapse in pregnancy is treated with the application of a ring pessary which should be kept in place until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy, when the body of the uterus is sufficiently enlarged to sit on the brim of the pelvis.

Patients may present with copious vaginal discharge and a decubitus ulcer may develop if the cervix remains outside the introitus. If the uterus does not rise above the pelvis by the 16th week of pregnancy, there is a chance of incarceration of the uterus.

The symptoms are mostly pronounced in early pregnancy.

There is an increased chance of miscarriage, premature rupture of membranes and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy.

Treatment involves the application of a ring pessary to keep the cervix in place. A ring pessary is also used to treat prolapse in very elderly women who cannot be surgically managed. It is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. It is also used in puerperium to facilitate involution.

The image below shows a ring pessary.

If the pelvic floor is too lax, the patient is advised to lie in bed with the foot end elevated, and the prolapsed mass is covered with a gauze soaked in glycerine and acriflavine. This is continued until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy till the prolapsed mass is reduced in size and replaced inside the vagina.

questions.text: A randomized clinical trial shows that a new antihypertensive X reduces systolic blood pressure significantly compared to the standard drug Y. (p-value: 0.03). The mean blood pressure after treatment in the control group is 138/80 mm Hg and in the intervention group receiving drug X is 136/78 mm Hg. What conclusions can be drawn?

choices.text: X does not reduce blood pressure significantly
The results are not valid due to confounders
There is recall bias in the study

questions.solution:
Drug X reduces systolic blood pressure compared to Y, with a p-value of 0.03. This means that the results are statistically significant. (Option A) However, the mean blood pressures in both the groups after treatment show us that the results are not clinically significant.

Note: Recall bias is seen in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Which of the following activates the alternate complement pathway?
questions.solution:
Lipopolysaccharide activates the alternate complement pathway.

The classical pathway of complement is activated by immune complexes or antigen-antibody complexes (Antigen bound to IgM or IgG).

Lipopolysaccharide of gram-negative bacteria, viral envelope, fungal balls, IgA/IgD aggregates activates the alternative complement pathway.

Binding of mannose-binding lectin to mannose residues (on the surfaces of Salmonella, Neisseria, and Listeria) activates the lectin complement pathway.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with fever and chills for the last 3 days. A peripheral blood smear showed the following feature. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing band forms in the erythrocyte suggests that P. malariae is the causative agent.

The older trophozoites of P.malariae are sometimes seen stretched across the erythrocyte as a broad band. These band forms are a unique feature of P. malariae. Numerous large pigment granules are also seen. Fine stippling called, Zeimann's stippling may be seen with special stains. P.malariae has the lowest degree of parasitization. 

P.vivax has ring forms that resemble P.malariae but they are thinner and less intensely stained. Erythrocytes are enlarged, and pale with Schuffner's dots. 

In P.ovale, the infected erythrocytes are slightly enlarged and oval shape with fimbriated margins. Prominent Schuffner's dots are present on the erythropcyte. 

Erythrocyte in P.falciparum initially will show marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shoes a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after the consumption of the seeds shown in the image. Which of the following is the toxin present in this seed?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are those of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is one of the toxic principles of this plant.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

The image below shows the seeds of Ricinus communis.

Option B- Crotin is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.

The image below shows the seeds of Croton tiglium.

Option D- Capsaicin is the toxic principle of Capsicum annum. Consuming in large doses causes difficulty in swallowing, abdominal pain, and inflammation of the esophagus and stomach.

The image below shows seeds of Capsicum annum.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, the intraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be ______.

choices.text: More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than one third  the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than half  the maximum preoperative value in 30 min

questions.solution:
Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. The size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. On examination, the external os is closed. USG shows a well-formed gestational sac with fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows a well-formed gestation ring indicating a healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Treatment involves bed rest, analgesics to relieve pain, and progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Trotter’s triad?
questions.solution:
Facial paralysis is not a part of the Trotter’s triad. Trotter’s triad is seen in nasopharyngeal cancer.

questions.text: Which of these is the correct formula to calculate Quetelet’s index?

choices.text: Weight in kg / Square of height in meters
Square of weight in kg/Height in meters
Weight in grams/square of height in meters
Square of weight in kg/Height in centimeters

questions.solution:
Quetelet’s index or body mass index (BMI) is calculated by weight in kg/square of height in meters. It is a method of assessing obesity.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the hospital due to diarrhea since 3 days. Laboratory values are as follows. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

pH = 7.2

PCO2 = 30 mmHg

HCO3 = 7 mEq/L

Cl = 120 mEq/L

Na = 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with an  increased anion gap

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate (HCO3) level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28 mEq/L) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence, this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- [(Cl-)+(HCO3-)]

= 135-(120+7)

= 8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence anion gap is within the normal range.

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 21 yr old man comes to the hospital for routine check-up. He has been taking secondary prophylaxis from the past 5 years due to an episode of acute rheumatic fever. He asks if he should continue taking the antibiotic. Which of the following information will determine your answer to his question?

choices.text: Duration of illness when it had occurred
The drug used for secondary prophylaxis
Presence or absence of carditis during illness
Presence or absence of erythema marginatum during illness

questions.solution:
The presence or absence of carditis during illness helps decide the duration of secondary prophylaxis.

In addition, the presence or absence of valvular disease also determines the duration of secondary prophylaxis.

Secondary prophylaxis is for patients with ARF. They are at a higher risk of developing a further episode of ARF after a group A streptococcal infection. They should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrences.

The best antibiotic for secondary prophylaxis is benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) delivered every 4 weeks. Oral penicillin V (250 mg) can be given twice daily instead but is less effective than benzathine penicillin G. Penicillin-allergic patients can receive erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the brisk Moro reflex seen?
questions.solution:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. 

In hypoglycemic babies, there is activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex which is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backwards onto the examiner’s hand.

An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities.

 The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

Other options:

  • In stage III hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), the muscles are flaccid and the infant is in a comatose state. So, Moro reflex is absent.
  • Kernicterus is characterized by the deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. So, Moro reflex is absent.
  • Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, Moro reflex is absent on the side of injury since the nerve supplying the muscles is affected.

 Moro reflex in different stages of Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

  • Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk
  • Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete
  • Stage III HIE (severe): Absent

questions.text: Which of the following is a small vessel vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener's granulomatosis) is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins. It is characterized by a triad of

  1. Necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tracts
  2. Focal necrotizing vasculitis most prominent in the lungs and upper airways
  3. Focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis, which is often crescentic

The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

Other options:

Option B: Temporal or Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis that causes chronic granulomatous inflammation of temporal, vertebral, ophthalmic arteries and aorta. The temporal artery is often biopsied to establish the diagnosis.

Option C: Kawasaki disease is an acute self-limiting illness affecting medium-sized arteries in children less than 4 years of age. Coronary arteries are affected which may cause aneurysm, thrombosis or myocardial infarction.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel disease primarily affecting the aortic arch and its branches. It causes ocular disturbances and weak pulse in the upper extremities, hence called pulseless disease.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

Related Pearl: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener’s granulomatosis) is a necrotising vasculitis of small arteries and veins along with granuloma formation.

It presents as a triad of upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with glomerulonephritis.

Important organs involved are:

  • Upper respiratory tract- Presents with paranasal sinus pain, serous otitis media, nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- Presents with cough, hemoptysis, and multiple bilateral cavitary nodular infiltrates.
  • Renal- Presents with rapidly progressive renal failure, crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Eye- Presents with conjunctivitis, scleritis, episcleritis and dacryocystitis
  • Skin- Papules, vesicles, palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.

Histopathology shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and vein with granuloma formation.

The important laboratory features are elevated ESR, positive cANCA  antibodies and mild elevation of rheumatoid factor.

Treatment:

  • Induction phase- Cyclophosphamide combined with steroids
  • Remission phase- Methotrexate/Azathioprine

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents to the OPD with symptoms of pain in both the knees since the past two years. She has been on calcium and vitamin D supplementation and is doing regular physical exercise. X-ray of the knee joint showed the following. Which would be the first line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. X Ray shows periarticular osteopenia around the knee joint.

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They specifically inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action:

Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Other Drugs:

  • Denosumab - This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate - It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. questions.text: The ligament indicated by the arrow has high levels of :
questions.solution:
The ligament shown by the arrow is Ligamentum flavum, which has high levels of elastin fibers.

The ligamentum flava are a series of ligaments that connect the ventral parts of the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. They predominantly contain elastic tissue and form part of the posterior surface of the vertebral canal. The high content of elastin allows it to be stretched by 80% without damage. The ligamentum flavum resists separation of the laminae in flexion and assists in extension back to the anatomical position.

questions.text: A young boy was hit by a cricket ball on his left eye. There was no restriction in ocular movements nor any visual disturbances. However, the ophthalmologist wanted to check for a foreign body. He used the instrument shown below. What is the false statement regarding this?

choices.text: It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle
It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber
It is used for the localization of a foreign body

questions.solution:

questions.text: A series of investigations usually done to diagnose dry eye are given below. Which of the following inference point towards a diagnosis of dry eye?

choices.text: Tear film breaks up at 16 seconds
Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm
No stain in Rose bengal staining
Inter eye difference of tear osmolarity 6 mOsm/L

questions.solution:
The Schirmer test strip had wet up to 9mm after 5 minutes. This is diagnostic of dry eye. In a normal eye, it gets wet >15 mm.

  • Tear film normally breaks up between 15-35 seconds. 
  • Staining should be present in Rose bengal staining to diagnose dry eye.
  • An inter eye difference of tear osmolarity >8 mOsm/L indicates tear film instability.

  • Surgical
