questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic, obese man presented to the OPD. His lipid profile showed hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated LDL and VLDL. Which of the following vitamins can be used for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and elevated LDL levels point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia or Type II hyperlipoproteinemia. Nicotinic acid (niacin or Vitamin B3) is used in treatment as a lipid-lowering drug. It lowers lipoprotein levels significantly.

Lipolysis in adipose tissues is the major producer of free fatty acids (FFA). The liver converts FFAs to triacylglycerol (TAG) which is used to synthesize very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) is derived from VLDL in the plasma. By inhibiting this lipolysis in adipose tissues, niacin causes a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides. So it is particularly useful in the treatment of type IIb hyperlipoproteinemia, in which both VLDL and LDL are elevated. Niacin also increases high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels and is prescribed at a dose of 1.5 grams per day.

The main adverse effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing and pruritus which can be controlled by pretreatment with aspirin. Niacin also causes hepatotoxicity, GI toxicity, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with severe mental retardation, seizures, white hair, and musty odour of body fluids. Which of the following is false about the condition?

choices.text: Musty odour is due to phenylalanine in sweat

questions.solution:
The above said clinical features are symptoms of phenylketonuria. A musty odour is due to phenylacetate in sweat.

Phenylketonuria:

  • Deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase(PAH) or its cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) causes accumulation of phenylalanine in body fluids and brain. Excess phenylalanine is metabolised to phenylacetate and phenylpyruvate.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • The infant is normal at birth. Intellectual disability develops when the infant remains untreated.

The newborn screening method of choice is the Tandem mass spectrometry.

The mainstay of treatment is phenylalanine restricted diet.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents to the outpatient for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guerin) vaccine would be indicated in this 3-week-old neonate at this visit as per the national immunization schedule. 

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine that can be given soon after birth until 1 year of age. It is given intradermally at the left upper arm. It provides protection against the central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis. The liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine are the types available. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine.

After 2-3 weeks of correct vaccine administration a papule develops at the site. Its size increases slowly and breaks into a shallow ulcer covered with a crust. Healing occurs within 6-12 weeks and will leave a permanent tiny round scar, which is a normal reaction. Adverse reactions seen with BCG vaccine administration are pain, swelling, redness, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, etc. 

The image below shows the BCG scar: 

Mission Indradhanush was launched to fully immunize children up to two years of age against seven vaccine-preventable diseases and pregnant women. The vaccines against the following diseases are included in this program diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, tuberculosis, polio, hepatitis B, and measles. It was later modified to the intensified mission indradhanush to further strengthen the immunization coverage.

Other Options:

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine given at birth until the first 24 hours. It is given intramuscularly on the anterolateral side of the mid-thigh. 

Option C: Oral polio vaccine-0 (OPV-0)  is a live attenuated vaccine given at birth until the first 15 days.

Option D: Injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is a killed whole organism vaccine given at 6 and 14 weeks of age.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an α1 adrenergic agonist?

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks, as seen in the image. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in stool. Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: It is a large vessel vasculitis
It is often accompanied by abdominal pain
There is mesangial IgA deposition in kidneys

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario describes Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) which is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood.

It is characterized by a purpuric rash mostly found on the lower extremities and buttocks and is commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. (Option C)

They may develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis: The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the mesangial deposition of polymeric IgA. (Option D)

Laboratory studies generally show mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count (Option A), and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal with a non-specific increase in total serum IgA levels.

Most clinical features of IgA vasculitis are self-limiting and resolve in a few days. Supportive management with the maintenance of hydration and pain relief is done. Patients developing nephritis due to IgA vasculitis may need aggressive management with immunosuppressants.

questions.text:
A premature male infant was born at 26 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 1150 g. He was diagnosed with respiratory distress syndrome and received continuous positive airway pressure for 2 weeks. As per the RBSK guidelines for universal eye screening in newborns, when should the baby be screened for retinopathy of prematurity?

RBSK- Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram
questions.solution:
In the scenario above, the gestational age is 26 weeks and birth weight is <1200 g, therefore, the infant must be screened at 3 weeks postnatal age as per the guidelines for the screening of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

Screening:

  • The first ROP screening should be done at 4 weeks if gestational age is 28–34 weeks or birth weight is <2000 g.
  • The first ROP screening should be done at 2-3 weeks if gestational age is <28 weeks or birth weight is <1200 g.
  • Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.

Retrolental fibroplasia is also known as retinopathy of prematurity.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), previously known as retrolental fibroplasia, is a disease of the eye that affects prematurely born babies.
  • ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. As such, all premature babies are at risk for ROP, and very low birth weight is an additional risk factor.
  • Both oxygen toxicity and relative hypoxia can contribute to the development of ROP.
  • Location

Concentric zones centred on the optic disc are described.

  • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the centre of the macula.
  • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the centre of the disc to the nasal ora Serrata.
  • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

Stages of ROP:

  • Stage 1: Demarcation line
  • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3: Neovascularization
  • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment

"Plus" disease signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus.

Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon but if untreated usually progresses to stage 5, sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of retinopathy.

Treatment:

  • Type 1. Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours for type 1 disease. It is done by laser photocoagulation of peripheral avascular retina.
  • Type 2 disease requires observation for progression.
  • Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents, e.g., bevacizumab (only for AP-ROP)
  • Laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina
  • Pars plana vitrectomy for tractional retinal detachment not involving the macula (stage 4A)

questions.text: A patient presents with a lower gastrointestinal bleed. Sigmoidoscopy shows ulcers in the sigmoid colon. The histopathological image of the biopsy from the ulcer is given below.  Which of the following is the infective form of this organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of E. histolytica.

In amebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

The following are the characteristic features of the various life stages of E. histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • It is found only in tissues.
  • Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance.
  • The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called the linin network, thus giving a cartwheel appearance.
  • Pseudopodia are present, which exhibit gliding motility.

The image given below shows the trophozoite form of E. histolytica.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars.
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst.

Cystic stage:

  • The mature cyst has 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.
  • Chromatid bars disappear.

The image given below shows the cyst form of E. histolytica.

Treatment involves three classes of drugs: 

  • Luminal amebicides like diloxanide furoate, paromomycin which act in the lumen
  • Tissue amebicides like emetine and chloroquine
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides like metronidazole and tinidazole.

The following image shows the life cycle and complications of E. histolytica.

questions.text: Tocilizumab acts by _______
questions.solution:
Tocilizumab is an IL -6 receptor antagonist. Therefore it prevents the binding of IL - 6 to its receptor, aborting its inflammatory response. Hence it is used as a biological disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drug (DMARD).

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 75-kg woman has a preoperative hematocrit of 35%. How much blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered? (Consider transfusion cut off of Hematocrit as 30%)
questions.solution:
750 ml blood loss can be allowed before transfusion needs to be considered

The transfusion point can be determined preoperatively from the hematocrit and by estimating blood volume. Patients with a normal hematocrit should generally be transfused only after losses greater than 10–20% of their blood volume. The exact point is based on the patient’s medical condition and the surgical procedure. The amount of blood loss necessary for the hematocrit to fall to 30% can be calculated as follows:

  1. Estimate blood volume
  2. Estimate the red blood cell volume (RBCV) at the preoperative hematocrit (RBCV preop).
  3. Estimate RBCV at a hematocrit of 30% (RBCV 30%), assuming normal blood volume is maintained.
  4. Calculate the RBCV lost when the hematocrit is 30%; RBCV lost = RBCV preop – RBCV 30%
  5. Allowable blood loss = RBCV lost x3.

Blood Volume

Neonates:

  • Premature 95 mL/kg
  • Full-term 85 mL/kg
  • Infants 80 mL/kg

Adults:

  • Men 75 mL/kg
  • Women 65 mL/kg

Estimated blood volume = 65 mL/kg x 75 kg = 4875 mL.

RBCV 35% = 4875 x 35% = 1706 mL.

RBCV 30% = 4875 x 30% = 1462 mL.

Red cell loss at 30% = 1706-1462 = 244 mL.

Allowable blood loss = 3 x 244 mL = 732 ~ 750ml

Therefore, transfusion should be considered only when this patient’s blood loss exceeds 750 ml.

Increasingly, transfusions are not recommended until the hematocrit decreases to 24% or lower (hemoglobin <8.0 g/dL), but it is necessary to take into account the rate of blood loss and comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects is seen in an injury to Baum’s loop of the optic radiations?
questions.solution:
Inferior quadrantanopia (pie in the floor) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations which pass through the parietal lobe. They are also known as Baum’s loop.

Pie in the Sky defects:

  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of inferior fibres of Optic radiations – Meyer’s loop
  • Seen in Temporal lobe lesions

Pie in the Floor defects:

  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of superior fibres of the Optic radiations – Baum’s loop
  • Seen in Parietal lobe lesions

Notable points :

  • Lesion in central chiasma – Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Lesion in anterior chiasma – Junctional scotoma
  • Lesion in optic tract – Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil
  • Radiational lesion and cortical blindness has normal pupillary reaction

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the opd with stridor. The laryngoscopic examination of the baby revealed the following condition. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is laryngomalacia, as the image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis. 

It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years. Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect on administering etomidate to a patient?
questions.solution:
Etomidate does not cause hemodynamic instability due to the lack of influence on the sympathetic nervous system and on baroreceptor functions. Due to this characteristic, etomidate is a useful anesthetic agent for patients with poor cardiac function and/or hemorrhagic shock. 

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent. Etomidate depresses the reticular activating system and mimics the inhibitory effects of GABA. It has a rapid onset with a shorter duration of action. 

Adverse effects include post-operative nausea and vomiting, myoclonus, pain at the injection site, and transient acute adrenal insufficiency.

Option A: Adrenocortical suppression is caused by inhibition of the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase resulting in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.

Option C: Thrombophlebitis, a side effect of etomidate, may be avoided by the use of the anesthetic's lipid formulation.

Option D: The incidence of myoclonus may be reduced by premedication with a hypnotic agent such as midazolam.

questions.text: Choose the correct pedigree chart for autosomal dominant inheritance:
questions.solution:
Among the given pedigrees, 'chart 1' is representative of an autosomal dominant type of inheritance.

In the autosomal dominant chart, we see that at least one parent of the index case is usually affected. It is manifested in the heterozygous state. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, there is a one in two chance of being affected by the disease. 

It is also seen that both males and females are affected by autosomal dominant inheritance patterns. Also, both males and females can transmit the condition.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

 

Option B shows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is seen that the parents of the affected individual are usually not affected and there is a one in four chance of being affected by the trait, among the siblings. 

Option C shows the X-dominant pattern of inheritance. This pattern of inheritance is caused by dominant alleles on the X chromosome. It is seen that an affected female parent transmits the disease to half her sons and half her daughters. An affected male parent with an unaffected female transmits it to all his daughters. None of his sons will be affected.

Option D shows the X-linked recessive pattern. Mutated genes on the X chromosome do not have corresponding alleles on the Y chromosome. Thus, males are hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes, and they express these disorders. A heterozygous female may express the disorder partially or may be a carrier.

questions.text: An intern was asked to show inversion and eversion of foot by his senior. Which of the following joints will not be involved in the movement shown by the intern?
questions.solution:
The tibiotalar joint is not involved in inversion and eversion movements of the foot. The tibiotalar joint is predominantly involved in plantar flexion and dorsiflexion of the foot.

Inversion and eversion movement takes place mainly at the talocalcaneal, calcaneocuboid, and talonavicular joints.

Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.

Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally.

The calcaneocuboid joint is at the same level as the talonavicular joint and together they represent the transverse tarsal joint.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young female came to the Dermatology OPD with non-acantholytic blisters. She was advised to get a histopathological examination of the lesion done which revealed the pathology shown in the image. The most likely diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
Bullous Pemphigoid is characterized by subepidermal (as shown in the image) non-acantholytic blisters.

As the antibodies in bullous pemphigoid are directed against BPAg2 and BPAg1 present in the basement membrane zone, intercellular junctions are intact and acantholysis is not seen. Hence the blisters that form are non-acantholytic.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:

  • Pemphigus and its variants (Options C and D)
  • Acantholytic dermatosis
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease
  • Warty dyskeratoma

Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:

  • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles) (Option A)
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Solar keratoses
  • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms like adenoid
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 

Other options:

Option A: Varicella has intraepidermal blisters.

Option C: Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

questions.text: An intern was asked to observe a histological section of the esophagus. What type of cells are seen by him in the basal layer of the epithelium of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the esophagus is the stratified squamous epithelium. The basal layer of cells present in the stratified squamous epithelium is composed of columnar cells.

The stratified squamous epithelium is made up of several layers of cells:

  • The cells in the deepest layer of the epithelium are columnar
  • The cells in the middle layers are polygonal
  • The cells in the superficial layers are flattened squamous cells

questions.text: A junior resident was asked to put a chemotherapy chart for a right side breast cancer patient who had ipsilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. He has put adriamycin, cyclophosphamide, paclitaxel and fludarabine in the regimen. During the daily rounds the senior resident saw the chemotherapy chart and advised ________.

choices.text: To continue the same therapy as it is the present chemotherapy regimen
To remove paclitaxel from the treatment chart and add topotecan
To remove fludarabine as it is not included in the present chemotherapy regimen
To continue the same therapy with the addition of topotecan to get additional advantage

questions.solution:
The senior resident advised junior resident to remove fludarabine from the chemotherapy chart as the present chemotherapy regimen used is ACT, i.e., Adriamycin, Cyclophosphamide, and Taxane (Paclitaxel).

Earlier regimens which are less commonly used currently are as follows:

  • CAF – Cyclophosphamide, Adriamycin, 5-Fluorouracil
  • CMF – Cyclophosphamide, Methotrexate, 5-Fluorouracil

Indications for chemotherapy in carcinoma breast:

  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache. Examination reveals localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, and bladder incontinence. On x-ray, paradiscal destruction of vertebrae is present.  Which of the following is the best management for the above patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache, localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, incontinence of his bladder, and paradiscal destruction of vertebrae seen on X-ray is likely to have Pott's paraplegia. Anterolateral decompression and antitubercular treatment are the best management for the above patient with Pott's paraplegia.

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The other patterns include central, posterior, and non-osseous involvement. 

Management of Pott’s paraplegia includes conservative management or surgery. 

Anti-tubercular chemotherapy forms the mainstay of treatment. The spine is put to absolute rest by a sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso- lumbar spine. If paraplegia improves, conservative treatment is continued. Bracing is continued for a period of about 6 to 12 months.

Surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Recurrence of the disease after treatment
  • Rapid onset paraplegia

Surgeries for Pott’s paraplegia include:

  • Antero-lateral decompression- surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris
  • Costotransversectomy- surgery indicated for paravertebral abscess
  • Laminectomy- indicated when the posterior parts of vertebrae are involved
  • Radical debridement and arthrodesis (Hongkong operation)

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination, his BMI is 41 kg/m2, blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg and an apnea-hypopnea index of 7. His awake arterial blood gas analysis is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

HCO3-: 25 mEq/L

PaCO2: 38 mmHg

PaO2: 98 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an obese patient with daytime sleepiness with an apnea-hypopnea index of 7 and normal ABG is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index and is calculated as number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.

Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in a ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG). This includes measurement of breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity.

Note that waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA suggests cardiopulmonary disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome (option B).

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty sustaining wakefulness and disturbed nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy usually feel well-rested on awakening and then feel tired throughout the day. One of the most characteristic clinical features which is seen is cataplexy – sudden muscle weakness without a loss of consciousness, which is usually triggered by strong emotions.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused due to increased sensitivity to PCO2. This causes an unstable breathing pattern, which manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Prolonged circulation delay between pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors is also a contributing cause. Hence, patients with heart failure may show CSA. They can present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

questions.text: The definitive host of Guinea worm is ____
questions.solution:
Man is the definitive host for guinea worm or Dracunculiasis. There is no animal reservoir.

Life cycle:

The adult worm, which is viviparous, discharges larvae, which are ingested by the freshwater crustacean Cyclops (the intermediate host). Humans get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infective cyclops. The larvae penetrate the wall of the duodenum and reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues. Here the larvae develop into male and female adults in about 3 to 4 months and mate.:

The fertilized female worm grows in size and migrates within the connective tissues and along fascial planes. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water. At this site, it sets up a local inflammatory reaction. The most common site affected is the leg, but other sites such as arms, shoulder, breast, buttocks, or genitalia may be affected. When the gravid female worm comes beneath the skin surface, it secretes a toxin which causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures, forming a shallow ulcer, in the base of which is a small hole through which the head of the worm protrudes. When the ulcer comes into contact with water, the worm contracts, discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous larvae.

They are swallowed by the freshwater copepod cyclops, which is the intermediate host. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and enter its body cavity where they moult twice. In about 2 to 4 weeks, they develop into the infective third-stage larvae.

This technique is called scintigraphy. Patients undergoing nuclear medicine testing emit ionising radiation. Gamma camera detects this radiation and converts it into an image.

This is used in various scintigraphie such as hepatobiliary scintigraphy, renal scintigraphy and ventilation-perfusion scintigraphy. They are also used in imaging modalities for breast cancer, prostate cancer, various PET and SPECT scans, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following leads to an increase in the power of a statistical test?
questions.solution:
Increasing the sample size will increase the power of a study. In fact, increasing the sample size is the most practical and most important way of increasing the power of a study.

Other factors that increase the power of a study are:

  • Increasing alpha
  • Decreasing beta
  • Decreasing sampling error
  • Increasing effect size (increase in difference between sample mean and hypothesized population mean)

questions.text: 35-year-old patient presented with a history of cold sores 2 days ago, now came with non-pruritic lesions on his elbow, as seen below. What type of hypersensitivity is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing target lesion is suggestive of Erythema Multiforme, which is due to Type 4 hypersensitivity.

Erythema Multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers.

Precipitating factors include HSV 1& 2 (commonly), EBV, and drugs like sulfa drugs (commonly).  This is consistent with the patient having history of cold sores.

The papules evolve into pathognomonic target or iris lesions that appear within a 72-hour period and begin on the extremities. Lesions remain in a fixed location for at least 7 days and then begin to heal.

questions.text: X is a drug that follows first-order kinetics. A 40 mg intravenous dose results in a plasma concentration of 2mg/L. What is the volume of distribution of this drug?
questions.solution:
Based on the parameters given, the volume of the distribution of the drug is 20 litres.

The volume of distribution, given by the following formula is used to calculate it.

Volume of distribution of drug (Vd) = Amount of drug administered in the body/ plasma concentration observed 

Here, the amount of drug administered to this patient is 40mg intravenously and the plasma concentration observed is 2 mg/litre. Substituting the values in the formula,

Vd=40/2=20 L

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with fever with chills and abdominal pain 2 days after vaginal delivery. She also has foul-smelling lochia. Parametrial tenderness is elicited on abdominal and bimanual examination. Her WBC count was 25000/ microlitre. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Anaerobic streptococcus is the predominant pathogen involved
Risk is more with vaginal delivery when compared with caesarian section
Placental site is involved most commonly following vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The risk of developing puerperal sepsis is more with a caesarian section when compared with vaginal delivery.

  • The most common route of spread of puerperal sepsis is direct spread.
  • The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in a cesarean section. (Option D)
  • The most common manifestation of puerperal infection is Endometritis. (Option C)
  • The most common cause of puerperal sepsis is Streptococcus. (Option A)
  • The most important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis is the route of delivery (Cesarean > Vaginal). (Option B)
  • The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following a cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of cesarean delivery. None of the other steps with respect to surgical closure of the abdomen have proven benefit in decreasing puerperal infection.

questions.text: A Chinese man was brought to the hospital with complaints of difficulty in breathing, fever, and chills. After admission, the patient developed rapidly progressive pulmonary edema. There is a history of coming in contact with a deer mouse burrow a few days back. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: The pathogen is classified under Bunyaviridae family
Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR
The case fatality rate is 30% or higher in pulmonary syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical picture and history are suggestive of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS). Human to human transmission is never reported in hantavirus infection.

  • Hantavirus is classified under Bunyaviridae.
  • Transmission to humans occurs by inhaling aerosols of rodent excreta.
  • Hantavirus causes:
    • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome
    • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is characterized by influenza-like illness followed rapidly by respiratory failure.
  • The case fatality rate is 30% or higher in hantavirus pulmonary syndrome
  • Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of abortion 3 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea and a desire for pregnancy. Her hysterosalpingography revealed multiple filling defects. Her hysteroscopy is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding her condition is false?

choices.text: It occurs due to endometrial damage
Risk of this syndrome is least following Dilatation and Curettage for PPH
It can cause recurrent abortions due to inadequate placentation

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and hysteroscopy is suggestive of asherman syndrome and the risk of developing it is the highest if D&C is done in the postpartum period. In postpartum hemorrhage, a greater area of the uterine wall is curetted, because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier.

Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to destruction of large areas of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion. Damage may also result from other uterine surgery and infection associated with an intrauterine device.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients can develop amenorrhea (in less severe cases), hypomenorrhea or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation.

Treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the method of autopsy that involves the removal of individual organs one by one?
questions.solution:
In the Virchow technique, the individual organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here, the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the nitric oxide (NO) ___________
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is derived from Arginine.

Nitric Oxide

  • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).
  • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • Mechanism of action:
    • NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation.
  • Effects of NO:
    • Vasodilation.
    • Neuromodulator in the brain.
    • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
    • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle
    • Penile erection.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery:

choices.text: The largest branch of the vertebral artery is the anterior inferior cerebellar artery
Anterior spinal artery supply anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
PICA disruption  leads to lateral medullary syndrome

questions.solution:
The largest branch of the vertebral artery is the Posterior inferior cerebellar artery(PICA).

The vertebral artery is a branch of the first part of the subclavian artery. It enters the skull through the foramen magnum and terminates by joining the vertebral artery of the opposite side forming the basilar artery. The branches of the cranial portion of the vertebral artery are:

  • Meningeal branches - supplying dura of posterior cranial fossa
  • Posterior spinal arteries - supply posterior one-third of the spinal cord
  • Anterior spinal artery - supply anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, cerebellar hemisphere, and the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.
  • Medullary branches - supplying the medulla

Clinical importance - A disruption in blood supply in the PICA leads to a lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: According to the sustainable development goals, by 2030, neonatal mortality and under 5 mortality should be reduced to _____ (per 1000 live births) and ______ (per 1000 live births) respectively:
questions.solution:
In sustainable development goals, target 3.2 aims to reduce neonatal mortality to 12/1000 live births and under 5 mortality to 25/1000 live births, by the year 2030.

There are 17 global goals and 169 targets set for 2030 as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030. Goals related to health are:

  • Goal 2- Reduce hunger, improve food security and improve nutrition
  • Goal 3- Ensure healthy lives and promote well being
  • Goal 6- Availability and management of water and sanitation

Important features of Goal 3 are (by 2030):

  • Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
  • End preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, and reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
  • End the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, etc.
  • Reduce mortality from non-communicable diseases and improve mental health
  • Prevent and treat substance abuse
  • Achieve universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs
  • Reduce deaths and illnesses from environmental pollution
  • Achieve universal health coverage for healthcare services.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which of the following amino acids will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280 nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Replacing alanine by tryptophan will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280 nm wavelength.

Amino Acids absorb UV light due to aromatic ring. Aromatic amino acids such as tyrosine, tryptophan, and phenylalanine absorb 250 to 290 nm UV light. The maximum absorption of UV light is by tryptophan. Because tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine, tryptophan makes the major contribution to the ability of most proteins to absorb light in the region of 280 nm.

Absorption of UV light by amino acids:

  • Amino acids do not absorb visible light and thus are colourless.
  • However, tyrosine, phenylalanine, and especially tryptophan absorb high-wavelength (250-290 nm) ultraviolet light
  • Compounds with conjugated double bonds absorb UV light. That is why aromatic amino acids, porphyrins, purine and pyrimidine bases absorb UV light. Among the aromatic amino acids, tryptophan absorbs the maximum.
  • Light absorbing capacity of aromatic amino acids is used to estimate the protein concentration with a spectrophotometer (an instrument that can measure the light absorbance from infrared to ultraviolet range).
  • With the absorbance value of a known concentration of protein solutions, a standard curve is made. The concentration of the protein is calculated using the standard curve.

The light absorption wavelength range of compounds:

Compound λ max (nm)(wavelength at which maximal light absorption occurs)
Peptide bond 190 - 230
Purine and pyrimidine bases 260
Aromatic amino acids 280
NADH & NADPH 340
Porphyrin 400

questions.text: Which of the following statements about endometriosis is false?

choices.text: The most common site of endometriosis is the fallopian tube
The most common symptom of endometriosis is dysmenorrhea
Danazol is used in the treatment of endometriosis

questions.solution:
The most common site of endometriosis is the ovary. Endometriosis of ovary is called an endometrioma.

The most common sites of occurrence: Ovary> Pouch of Douglas> Uterosacral ligament> Broad ligament >Fallopian tube.

Endometriosis:

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

It is a proliferative hormonal dependent disease of the childbearing period.

Most common age group: 30-40 years.

Treatment of endometriosis

Medical management:

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDs DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

 

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogue
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.
  • Best time to conceive, in a patient of endometriosis is immediately after surgery.

questions.text: Which among the following is a contraindication for induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Active genital herpes is a contraindication for induction of labor. 

The fetus becomes affected by the virus shed from the cervix or lower genital tract during vaginal delivery. The risk of fetal infection is high in primary genital HSV due to high virus shedding compared to a recurrent infection. Caesarian delivery is indicated in an active primary HSV infection where the membranes are intact or recently ruptured.

Abruptio placentae, oligohydraminos and Rh-isoimmunization are indications for induction of labor.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissue and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. 

Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-ds DNA antibodies and  Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE.

Option D- Anti-SRP antibodies are characteristically seen in necrotizing myopathies.

questions.text: Reflux of urine into the renal pelvis, calyces with moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces, indicates __________  vesicoureteric reflux.
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into the renal pelvis, calyces with moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces, indicates grade 4 vesicoureteral reflux.

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE                                      DESCRIPTION
              I Reflux into a nondilated ureter
             II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation
             III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
             IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
              V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyces; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is less active in Type 1 diabetes mellitus?

questions.text: All are true regarding sirtuins except?
questions.solution:
Sirtuins increase insulin sensitivity (not resistance)

Sirtuins are a family of NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. They help in adapting to various environmental stresses, including food deprivation and DNA damage.

Sirtuins promote the expression of several genes whose products increase longevity. These include proteins that

  • Inhibit metabolic activity
  • Reduce apoptosis
  • Stimulate protein folding
  • Inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen-free radicals
  • Increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism (may be targeted for the treatment of diabetes).

Sirtuins level increases by caloric restriction and are present in red wine.

questions.text: A baby boy at 7 months of age presented with a history of vomiting and failure to thrive. On evaluation, he is found to have raised blood ammonia levels and no ketones. Also, he has high plasma glutamine and alanine levels, with low levels of citrulline and arginine. Which is the enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The enzyme likely to be deficient in this baby is ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC). 

In this X-linked disorder, males are more severely affected than females. In this disorder, there are episodes of hyperammonemia which is manifested by vomiting, and neurologic abnormalities like ataxia, mental confusion, agitation, combativeness, and frank psychosis. These episodes are separated by the period of wellness.

Laboratory findings during the acute attack:

  • Hyperammonemia is accompanied by marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine. High glutamine in urine is usually seen in hyperammonemia as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.
  • The blood level of urea is low.
  • A marked increase in the urinary excretion of orotic acid. Orotate precipitates in urine as pink-colored gravel or stones.
  • Increased uracil in urine is also seen. When OTC is deficient carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria spills into the cytoplasm then it enters into pyrimidine synthesis. 

 The diagnosis is most conveniently confirmed by gene analysis.

Other options:

Option A: In the near-complete enzymatic deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1, symptoms appear during the 1st few days or even hours of life. the baby presents with the signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia (refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, convulsion, coma). Increased intracranial pressure is frequent. Orotic aciduria and increased production of pyrimidines like uracil in this case are not seen in Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 deficiency.

Option C: Arginase deficiency is a rare distal urea cycle disorder that presents as acute neonatal form with intractable seizures, cerebral edema, and death. Laboratory findings include marked elevations of arginine in plasma and CSF.

Option D: The deficiency of the Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme leads to citrullinemia type I, also called classic citrullinemia.  The severe or neonatal form (the most common form) appears in the 1st few days of life with signs and symptoms of hyperammonemia. In the subacute or mild form, clinical findings such as failure to thrive, frequent vomiting, developmental delay, and dry, brittle hair appear gradually after 1 year of age. Laboratory findings are similar to those found in patients with OTC deficiency, except that the plasma citrulline concentration is greatly elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 58-year-old female complains of difficulty in walking downstairs because everything appears to be in doubles when she is looking down. She is also a known diabetic for the past 20 years and non-compliant to anti-diabetic medications. What could be the reason for her double vision?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests trochlear nerve palsy.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia

Hence, the patient will have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in an adducted position. Diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis affect the vasa nervosum of the cranial nerves leading to ischemia of the nerves. It results in paralysis.

Other options:

  • In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve)
    • Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.
  • In 6th nerve palsy (abducens nerve)
    • Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired and not depression.

questions.text: What is the function of H1 histone?

choices.text: The central role in the formation of nucleosome
Stabilize the primary particle and firmly bind two additional half turns of DNA
Stabilize the 30 nm chromatin fiber made up of six to seven supercoiled nucleosomes
Acetylation or deacetylation is associated with the activation or inactivation of gene transcription

questions.solution:
H1 histones stabilize 30 nm chromatin fibre made up of six to seven supercoiled nucleosomes.

H2A, H2B, H3 and H4 are called core histones. They form octamers made up of two units of each core histone. DNA is wrapped around this octamer to form a nucleosome.

Acetylation and Deacetylation of H3 and H4 histones is associated with the activation or inactivation of gene transcription.

questions.text: A patient who was hospitalized and started on an intravenous antibiotic has developed diarrhea. The findings of the colonoscopy are given below. Which of the following antibiotic is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis most likely due to clindamycin. 

Pseudomembranous colitis is an advanced form of clostridium difficile infection (CDI) that is visualized at endoscopy. Pseudomembranes are seen as whitish yellow plaques on the mucosa. Clostridium difficile infection is the most commonly diagnosed nosocomial diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, that causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora. This leads to the colonization of C. difficile.

Antibiotics that may cause CDI are:

  • Clindamycin
  • Ampicillin
  • Cephalosporins- cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, and ceftazidime
  • Fluroquinolones- ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin

Clinical features include diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria: 

  • Diarrhea without other recognized causes, and
  • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool 

Discontinuation of the offending antimicrobial, if possible, is the first step in management. Oral vancomycin and fidaxomicin (Option B) are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

Other options:

Option A: Daptomycin may cause allergic pneumonitis in patients receiving prolonged therapy for more than 2 weeks.

Option D: Chloramphenicol is mainly associated with adverse effects such as bone marrow suppression, and hypersensitivity reactions. When given to infants, it may cause grey baby syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female came to the surgical outpatient department with a swelling in the neck. On clinical examination, it was determined to be a thyroid swelling with a suspected extension into retrosternum. What is the imaging modality of choice to determine the extension of swelling in deciding management?
questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice to determine the extension of thyroid swelling in deciding management is a CT scan.

Other options :

Option B: Chest radiograph can be used to predict the retrosternal extension of thyroid but it is not imaging modality of choice.

Option C: MRI is not used to determine the extension of thyroid swelling.

Option D: Ultrasonography is used to determine the type of thyroid swelling, visualization of neck lymph nodes and extension to the soft tissue but its use is limited in determining extension to retrosternum.

questions.text: Delamanid is a nitroimidazole oxazole compound. Identify the incorrect statement about delamanid.

choices.text: Acts by inhibition of synthesis of mycolic acid
In India, it is approved for use in MDR-TB
Approved for use in children above 6 years of age
Approved for use in pregnant women

questions.solution:
The false statement about delamanid is approved for use in pregnant women, it is rather contraindicated in pregnancy.

Delamanid acts by inhibition of synthesis of mycolic acid. Pretomanid and Delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria.

Delamanid is approved for use in MDR-TB and was recently approved in India (August 2017).

It is approved for use in children above 6 years of age. However, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chest pain. He is diagnosed to have acute MI complicated by severe mitral regurgitation. X-Ray shows peribronchial cuffing and perihilar haze. Multiple air bronchograms and short parallel lines at the periphery of the lung fields can be seen. 2 D Echo shows an ejection fraction of 35%. What is false about this kind of respiratory failure?

choices.text: It is a type IV respiratory failure
Intubation and mechanical ventilation are treatment modalities
Caused by hyperperfusion of respiratory muscles

questions.solution:
Acute MI with severe mitral regurgitation combined with an EF of 35 % is suggestive of cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock results in a type IV respiratory failure. Type 4 respiratory failure is not caused due to hyperperfusion of respiratory muscles. Instead, it results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock.

All other statements are true regarding Type IV respiratory failure.

Type IV respiratory failure:

Patients in cardiogenic shock → Pulmonary edema (Chest X-Ray findings in this patient)  → respiratory distress → increased requirement of oxygen delivery (Increases from < 5% to 40 % of cardiac output)

The inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles causes type IV respiratory failure Intubation and mechanical ventilation can allow redistribution of the cardiac output away from the respiratory muscles and back to vital organs while the shock is treated.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about serotonin syndrome is false?

choices.text: Cyproheptadine is used for its management
Autonomic symptoms are due to noradrenaline release
Occurs with SSRIs and MAO inhibitors combination
Raised CPK is characteristically seen in serotonin syndrome

questions.solution:
Serum CPK levels are usually normal, raised only in neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT (eg, MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, dextromethorphan).

Co-prescription of the abovementioned causative drugs results in increasing serotonin levels, that increase norepinephrine levels which is responsible for the autonomic symptoms in serotonin syndrome.

Characterized by 3 A’s:

Neuromuscular hyperActivity (clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure), Autonomic stimulation (hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhoea), and Agitation.

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist).

questions.text: A 3 day old boy has microcephaly, small palpebral fissures and absent philtrum. He is small for gestational age and echocardiogram shows an atrial septal defect. Which of the following substances did his mother most likely use during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
This small for gestational baby with microcephaly, small palpebral fissures, absent philtrum and an atrial septal defect most likely has fetal alcohol syndrome due to maternal alcohol use in pregnancy.

The presence of at least one of the below characteristics is defined as fetal alcohol syndrome:

  •  Growth restriction before and/or after birth
  • Facial anomalies: small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, lowset and unparallel ears, retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Microcephaly, mental retardation, abnormal neurobehavioral development (attention deficit with hyperactivity)

Other features:

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly
  • Agenesis of corpus callosum and the cerebellar vermis.
  • Cardiac anomalies :VSD>ASD ,tetralogy of fallot.

Other Options:

Option A: Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterised by digital hypoplasia, microcephaly, cleft lip, cleft palate and other minor craniofacial abnormalities.

Option B: Maternal use of opioids causes neonatal abstinence syndrome which presents with fever, yawning, sneezing, vomiting and seizures. 
 
Option C: Maternal use of lithium leads to Ebsteins anomaly and macrosomia.

questions.text: Which of the following part of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), marked as "1" in the above image of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption.

The structures marked in the image are as follows:

  1. PCT
  2. Distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
  3. Loop of Henle
  4. Collecting duct

PCT reabsorbs about 67% of the filtered water. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT i.e. the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and are proportional to each other. Here the solute that is reabsorbed along with the water is Na+. So 67% of both flitered Na+ and water are reabosrbed in the PCT. 

These large amounts of Na+ and water reabsorption is essential in maintaining the ECF volume. 

In addition to the isosmotic reabsorption, the water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through the active water channels known as aquaporin-1.

questions.text: A 50-year-old known diabetic and chronic smoker is brought to the hospital due to sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. His cardiac troponins are elevated. His ECG shows complete heart block. Which of the following JVP waves is likely to be abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical features suggestive of acute myocardial infarction and has a complete heart block. In this patient, an abnormality may be seen in 'a' wave of the JVP, labeled as 'A' in the given image.  

The 'a' wave is representative of the presystolic contraction of the right atrium. Patients with complete AV block have cannon 'a' waves in the JVP due to the contraction of atria against the closed tricuspid valve.

Causes of canon ‘a’ waves include:

  • Complete AV block
  • Ventricular tachycardia
  • Premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats

Complete heart block (Third-degree AV block): The ECG shows severe bradycardia, junctional escape rhythm, and independent P (red arrows) and QRS complexes (green arrow):

questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with a recent history of having consumed pork presented to the hospital with severe headache, vomiting, episodes of convulsions, and dies. The brain autopsy shows numerous small cysts containing scolices in a milky fluid. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the autopsy findings of multiloculated cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulosae).

Neurocysticercosis is the most common CNS parasitic infection. 

The pork tapeworm T. solium can cause two distinct forms of infection in humans: (1) adult tapeworms in the intestine or (2) larval forms (cysticerci) in the tissues (called cysticercosis). By ingesting undercooked pork containing cysticerci, humans acquire infections that lead to intestinal tapeworms. Infections that cause human cysticercosis follow the ingestion of T. solium eggs.

In cysticercosis, the clinical manifestations are variable. Cysticerci can be found anywhere in the body, most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye. Neurologic manifestations (neurocysticercosis) are the most common. The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include

  • Features of increased intracranial tension like headache, nausea, ataxia, confusion, papilloedema, and altered mental status
  • Epilepsy
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Transient paresis
  • Behavioral disorders
  • Aphasia
  • Visual disturbances.

Definitive diagnosis of cysticercosis is by biopsy of the lesion and its microscopic examination to show the invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks. Neuroimaging criteria include detection of dead calcified cysts by CT scan of brain. The cysticercal lesions appear as a small ring like hypodensities with a bright central spot. Clinical criteria includes detection of specific anticysticercal antibodies or cysticercal antigens by well- standardized immunodiagnostic tests. 

NOTE:

About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.
