questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with a diuretic for heart failure. He now presents with complaints of hearing impairment and dizziness. Which diuretic is likely to be associated with these side effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects, causing ototoxicity.

Loop diuretics have the potential to cause damage to the ears, resulting in symptoms such as ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing impairment, dizziness, and a feeling of fullness in the ears. The risk of ototoxicity is highest when loop diuretics are administered rapidly through an intravenous route and lowest when taken orally. To prevent ototoxicity, it is important to avoid infusing furosemide at a rate of more than 4 mg/min.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is used in cases of acute pulmonary oedema, cerebral oedema, hypertension, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Other options:

Option B: Thiazides act on the DCT. They inhibit Na+-Cl− symporter present in the distal convoluted tubule. It is used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic oedema. Their adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

Option C: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal convoluted tubule. Used to treat glaucoma and mountain sickness and to alkalinize urine. Side effects are acidosis, hypokalaemia, fever, rashes, and paresthesia. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Option D: Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide selective V2 receptor antagonist. Its main mechanism of action is to enhance the excretion of free water by the kidneys, which helps restore normal sodium levels in the blood. It is a new addition to the treatment options for hyponatremia caused by congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). The most common side effects of this medication include increased thirst and a dry sensation in the mouth. Other possible side effects are fever, gastrointestinal disturbances, and elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text:
The suture application shown in the given image will be most useful in the management of which of the following conditions?

(PPH- Postpartum hemorrhage)

choices.text: PPH caused due to  HELLP syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a B-lynch suture. It is most useful in the management of PPH caused due to polyhydramnios.

It is a technique to control severe atonic postpartum hemorrhage, which can occur as a result of polyhydramnios. B-lynch suture involves the use of vertical brace sutures, which oppose the anterior and posterior walls of the uterus. This leads to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the hemorrhage.

Predisposing factors for PPH are:

  • Atonic PPH:
    • Grand multipara
    • Previous history of PPH
    • Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, polyhydramnios, macrosomia
    • Precipitate labor, prolonged labor
    • Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
    • Labor induction or augmentation with oxytocin
    • Placental anomalies: Placenta previa/ accreta/ increta/ percreta/ abruptio placenta
  • Traumatic PPH:
    • Instrumental deliveries
    • Episiotomy
  • PPH due to Coagulopathy:
    • Sepsis
    • IUD
    • HELLP syndrome

For PPH due to Coagulopathy - transfusion of blood products such as Fresh frozen plasma, cryoprecipitate, platelet concenterate is given.

questions.text: Excessive ingestion of iodine in a person who is not iodine deficient causes?
questions.solution:
Excess iodine transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification and is known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Other options:

  • Jod-Basedow phenomenon: Hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production by autonomous nodules following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances in patients with endemic iodine deficiency.
  • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Ingestion of excess thyroid hormone leading to thyrotoxicosis without hyperthyroidism.
  • De Quervain's thyroiditis (subacute thyroiditis, granulomatous thyroiditis or viral thyroiditis): Characterized by inflammatory infiltrate leading to initial hyperthyroid phase due to follicular destruction followed by a hypothyroid phase due to thyroid hormone depletion.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis?
questions.solution:
Condyloma lata is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis.

These are highly contagious exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area, and upper thighs.

Secondary syphilis occurs within 6 weeks to 8 weeks of the onset of the primary chancre. It is characterized by the following:

  • The onset of systemic manifestations includes symptoms such as malaise, headache, loss of appetite, and sore throat
  • Generalized symmetric, asymptomatic maculopapular rash on the palms and soles of the feet
  • Generalized adenopathy in 50% of cases
  • Condyloma lata

Other options: 

  • A chancre is seen in primary syphilis. These are painless indurated ulcer(s) with a punched-out base and rolled out edges. They appear within 9-90 days from the first exposure.
  • Pseudo chancre redux is seen in tertiary syphilis. It is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer. 
  • Aortitis is also a feature of tertiary syphilis.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo surgery.  His past medical records reveal that he is homozygotic for the atypical pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following would you expect to encounter in this patient on administering succinylcholine?

choices.text: A rapid onset of action and a short duration of action
Delayed onset and a short duration of action

questions.solution:
A prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine would be expected in a patient with atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme.

Succinylcholine is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase as soon as it enters the circulation. This results in the short duration of action of succinylcholine, which is usually less than 10 minutes. 

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase, resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defect, cannot metabolize succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action. In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2–20 minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4–8 hours. The incidence of atypical pseudocholinesterase genes is more common in those with European ancestry.

The rapid onset of action of succinylcholine is because of its small volume of distribution resulting from very low lipid solubility. The onset is not affected by the atypical pseudocholinesterase.

questions.text: Which group of lab parameters is most suggestive of Von Willebrand disease?

choices.text: Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Prolonged aPTT
Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Normal aPTT
Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT
Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT

questions.solution:
Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT is seen in Von - Willebrand disease. Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet mediated hemostasis.

Other options:

Choice A: Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Prolonged aPTT is seen in deficiencies of common pathway factors (I, II, V, X), liver disease, DIC, direct thrombin inhibitors, direct factor Xa inhibitors.

Choice B: Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Prolonged PT, Normal aPTT is seen in factor VII deficiency, mild Vitamin K deficiency, warfarin use.

Normal Platelet count, Normal BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT are seen in Hemophilia A and B.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida with 32 weeks of gestation presents to your antenatal clinic with preterm labour. You consider adding a tocolytic for the same. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Dinoprostone is an oxytocic and not a tocolytic.

Dinoprostone, a naturally occurring prostaglandin E2(PGE2) is used in the induction of labour and management of postpartum haemorrhage.

Ritodrine, terbutaline, and nifedipine are tocolytics that are indicated for inhibition of uterine contractions of preterm labour but not for prophylaxis against preterm labour.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical manifestations of infective endocarditis is an immune-mediated phenomenon?
questions.solution:
White centered retinal hemorrhages are an immune-mediated phenomenon. They are also known as Roth spots.

The immunological phenomenon in infective endocarditis:

  • Roth's spots
  • Osler’s node
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Rheumatoid factor

Mnemonic: ROGeR

Vascular phenomena in infective endocarditis:

  • Major arterial emboli
  • Septic pulmonary infarcts
  • Mycotic aneurysm
  • Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Conjunctival hemorrhages
  • Janeway lesions

questions.text: The Base of the heart is not formed by:

choices.text: Proximal part of superior vena cava

questions.solution:
Left ventricle is not involved in forming the base of the heart.

The base of the heart is a quadrilateral directed posteriorly. It is made of:

  • The left atrium mainly
  • Small part of the right atrium
  • Proximal parts of superior vena cava, inferior vena cava, and pulmonary veins

The base of the heart lies at the level of the T5-T8 vertebrae in the supine position.

The apex of the heart is formed by the left ventricle in the 5th intercostal space.

Surfaces of the heart:

  • Sternocostal surface - Formed by the right atrium, right and left ventricles
  • Diaphragmatic surface - Formed mainly by the left ventricle
  • Left surface - Formed mainly of the left ventricle
  • Right surface - Formed mainly of the right atrium

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with headache. He also has a family history of glaucoma. On examination, intraocular pressure was 23 and 24 mmHg in the right and left eye respectively. Iridocorneal angles were normal on gonioscopy. There was no visual field defects. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition of the patient? (POAG- Primary open-angle glaucoma)

choices.text: Thin cornea is a risk factor for POAG development
Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the onset of POAG
Increased cup disc ratio is a risk factor for POAG development
Younger people are more at risk for progression to POAG than older people

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the patient points towards ocular hypertension. Older people are more at risk of progression than younger people.

Ocular hypertension (OHT) is characterized only by raised intraocular pressure (IOP). The optic disc and visual fields are normal, with no evidence of angle closure.

Significant risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to primary open-angle glaucoma include the following:

  • Increased IOP
  • Increasing age
  • Increased cup-disc ratio
  • Thin cornea 
  • African-American race
  • Male gender
  • Associated heart disease

Evaluating the option statements on their own merit can help rule out the other 3 options and arrive at the correct answer, irrespective of solving the clinical scenario. At times, the clinical scenario may not really be essential to arriving at the answer.

questions.text: An intern in ICU decides to insert a central venous catheter through a femoral vein in a burns victim to administer IV fluids. However, while inserting the needle, he accidentally injured a solid structure lying immediately medial to the femoral vein, lying within the femoral sheath. Which of the following drains into the injured structure?
questions.solution:
Deep inguinal lymph node (also known as the node of Cloquet) lies medial to the femoral vein and is likely to be injured in this case. The glans penis drains into the deep inguinal lymph node whereas, the rest of the penis drains into the superficial lymph nodes.

The scrotum drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Femoral sheath is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains the femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains the femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains lymphatic vessels, areolar tissue, and lymph node of Cloquet.

questions.text: A screening test that has 80% sensitivity is done on two towns A and B. The prevalence of the disease is 10% in A and 40% in B. What does a positive test result mean?

choices.text: The person definitely has the disease, whether he lives in A or B
The person does not have the disease, whether he lives in A or B
A person living in A who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive

questions.solution:
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive.

The predictive value of a positive test indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease (true positive). This predictive value depends on the sensitivity, specificity, and the disease prevalence. If the disease is more prevalent in a given population, the predictive value of the positive screening test will be more accurate. Hence, a positive test in a person living in town B, which has a higher prevalence is more likely to be a true positive.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Swirl sign. It is an area of low attenuation within an extraaxial hyperattenuating fluid collection.

The term "swirl sign" describes the appearance on a non-contrast CT scan when fresh blood leaks into a hematoma, such as in intracerebral, extradural, or subdural hematomas. This indicates the presence of unclotted blood, which appears lighter than the surrounding clotted blood.
 

Other options:

  • Mount Fuji sign - This sign is present in case of pneumocephalus. Gas is present between the tips of the frontal lobes with heaped up appearance giving the silhouette-like appearance.
  • Ice cream cone sign-it represents the normal appearance of malleus and incus on an HRCT.
  • Accordion sign/concertina sign is a non-specific sign related to a thickened edematous large bowel wall usually seen in CT abdomen of patients with infectious colitis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male complains of easy fatiguability and tiredness present throughout the day. On clinical examination, a mass is felt in the right iliac fossa. Blood examination shows Hb of 8 g/dl, MCV of 60fl/cell, MCH of 24pg/cell. Colonoscopy is done and shows a growth in the proximal ascending colon. Histopathological examination of the growth is as below. What is the preferred surgical treatment?
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of the growth in the proximal ascending colon growth is suggestive of adenocarcinoma. In a patient with adenocarcinoma of the proximal colon, the preferred surgery is right hemicolectomy. Blood examination finding is suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia which occurs due to iron deficiency due to bleeding from the tumor. Right hemicolectomy is done in the patient who has carcinoma of the caecum and ascending colon. Right extended hemicolectomy is done in the patient who has carcinoma of the transverse colon and splenic flexure.

Left hemicolectomy is the operation of choice for descending colon and sigmoid colon cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the given image is ligated in the case of refractory posterior epistaxis?
questions.solution:
In the given image, structure marked B is the sphenopalatine artery which is ligated in the case of refractory posterior epistaxis. Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleed. Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred method. It is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate.

Other structures marked:

A - Anterior ethmoidal artery,

C – Posterior ethmoidal artery

D – Greater palatine artery

questions.text: A person with a gunshot wound of size 3 cm presents with a comminuted fracture of the tibia. On examination, the distal pulse could not be felt. Which grade does this belong to according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
The above-described wound belongs to grade IIIC according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification.

Gustilo and Anderson's classification is the most commonly followed classification for open fractures.

An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

questions.text: The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves in hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, respectively, shift to
questions.solution:
In cases of hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right and left, respectively.

In carbon monoxide poisoning, the affinity of Hb for CO is about 200 times more than that for O2, and hence, the COHb releases the CO into the blood very slowly. The O2–Hb dissociation curve of the remaining hemoglobin shifts to the left.

Graph of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve in anemia was tested recently in INICET May 2023. In chronic anemia, there is marked hemoglobin deficiency associated with increased 2-3, DPG in red blood cells, and as a result, the O2- Hb dissociation curve shifts to the right.

questions.text: What is the function of the structure marked in the below image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the second lumbrical, which is responsible for extending both the interphalangeal joints.

It also causes flexion of metacarpophalangeal joints. The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered a head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the correctly matched "memory deficit vs structure" pair indicating the memory deficit he would suffer if the mentioned structure were to be damaged.
questions.solution:
Declarative memory involves the medial temporal lobe and hippocampus  for retention.

Other options:

Procedural memory - Striatum.

Priming and perceptual - Neocortex

Associative learning-  Amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A woman with 31 weeks of gestation presents with lower abdominal pain. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a U shaped cervix. Which of the following will be true in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the U shaped cervix points towards the diagnosis of preterm labour where fetal fibronectin value will be greater than 50ng/ml (or 0.05mg/l).

Shape of the cervix on TVS: Seen in:
T shaped Normal
Y shaped Suspicion of preterm labour
U shaped  Incompetent os, preterm labour

Fibronectin detection in cervicovaginal secretions before membrane rupture is a possible marker for impending preterm labor.

Fetal fibronectin:

  • Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amniotic fluid.
  • It aids in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in the maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua.
  • The value of fetal fibronectin predictive of preterm labour is >50 ng/ml.
  • Fetal fibronectin is measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and values exceeding 50 ng/mL are considered positive.

questions.text: The ‘y’ descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to _______ phase of the cardiac cycle.
questions.solution:
The ‘y’ wave in jugular venous pressure corresponds to ventricular diastole of the cardiac cycle.

The jugular venous pulse:

  • The waves in JVP reflect the pressure changes in the right atrium.
  • The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.

a wave: Corresponds to right atrial contraction.

c wave: Corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.

x descent: Corresponds to the atrial relaxation as the ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve.

v wave: Corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.

y descent: Corresponds to fall in right atrial pressure during passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: The pre-anesthetic evaluation of a 33-year-old male who has been posted for surgery is conducted, and the oral cavity examined is as depicted in the image given below. This would be______________ according to Mallampati classification.
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class II.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered risk factors for difficult ventilation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A mother brings her child to the OPD. The child is able to run, speak 2-3 word sentences and use a spoon. He doesn't know his name and cannot ride a tricycle. Assuming normal development, what is this child's age most likely to be?
questions.solution:
The ability to handle a spoon well, run well and speak 3 word sentences usually developed by 24 months. 

Because this child doesn't know his name, he is unlikely to be older than 30 months. 

Some key milestones of children from 15 months of age are listed below:

Age Motor milestones Adaptive milestones Language milestones Social milestones
15 months Walks alone, crawls up stairs. Makes tower of 3 blocks, draws a line with crayon, inserts raisin or coin into bottle. Jargon, follows simple commands, may name familiar objects, responds to own name. Hugs parents, indicates some desires or needs by pointing.
18 months Runs stiffly, sits on a small chair, walks up stairs with 1 hand held, explores drawers. Makes tower of 4 blocks, imitates scribbling. 10 words (average), names pictures, identifies 1 or more body parts. Feeds self, seeks help when in trouble, may complain when wet or soiled.
24 months Runs well, walks up and down stairs – 1 step at a time, opens doors, jumps. Makes tower of 7 blocks, scribbles in circular pattern, fold paper once in imitation. Puts 3 words together. Handles spoon well, helps to undress, tells immediate stories, listen to stories when pictures are involved.
30 months Goes up stairs alternating feet. Makes tower of 9 blocks, makes vertical and horizontal strokes but not a cross. Refers to self with pronoun ‘I’, knows full name. Pretends during play, helps put things away.
36 months Rides tricycle, stands momentarily on 1 foot. Makes tower of 10 blocks, imitates construction of bridge with 3 blocks, copies circle, imitates cross. Knows age and sex, counts 3 objects correctly, repeats 3 numbers or a sentence of 6 syllables. Helps in dressing, washes hands, plays games (in parallel with other children).
48 months Hops on 1 foot, throws ball overhand, uses scissors to cut pictures, climbs well. Copies bridge from model, imitates construction of gate with 5 blocks, copies cross and square, identifies longer of 2 lines. Counts 4 coins correctly, tells story. Goes to toilet alone, plays with several children.
60 months Skips Draws triangle from copy, names the heavier of two weights. Names 4 colors, speaks sentence of 10 syllables, counts 10 coins correctly. Dresses and undresses, asks questions about meaning of words, engages in domestic role-playing.

questions.text: A 46 yr old woman from Arunachal Pradesh presents with fever and chills, which are followed by profuse sweating. Blood smear examination confirms Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following drugs are used for treatment?
questions.solution:

questions.text: During the autopsy, the forensic expert performed the incision test after seeing the following changes on the skin of the body. What is the reason behind performing this test?

choices.text: To determine the cause of death.
To differentiate antemortem bruise from postmortem hypostasis.
It helps determine the methemoglobin level in the blood.
It clears the site of examination and improves the field of view during the autopsy.

questions.solution: The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test.The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels (contusion or bruise).

questions.text: A teenager presents to the OPD with fever, malaise and lymphadenopathy. Heterophile agglutination test is positive, The causative virus uses the complement receptor ____________ to attach to and infect B cells?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described here is of infectious mononucleosis. The causative virus is the Epstein-Barr virus. It uses the complement receptor CD 21 to attach to and infect B cells.

EBV infects B lymphocytes and possibly epithelial cells of the oropharynx. The infection of B cells is latent; that is, there is no viral replication and the cells are not killed. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the ability to propagate indefinitely in vitro.

CD 10, 22 are B cell markers but are not used by EBV to infect B cells.

CD 3 is a T cell marker.

questions.text: A young woman presented with a history of discharge from the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo syndrome. 

Patients with petrositis may present with Gradenigo syndrome. Gradenigo syndrome is a triad with the following symptoms:

  • Diplopia or double vision due to cranial nerve VI  palsy
  • Facial pain or deep-seated ear pain due to cranial nerve V involvement
  • Persistent ear discharge due to otitis media

The patient may also have a fever, headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity. The involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves results in facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo respectively.

Diagnosis of petrositis is done by a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of the temporal bone shows bony details of the air cells and petrous apex. MRI helps to detect the presence of fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Other options:

Option A: Griesinger sign is edema over the mastoid, which is secondary to the thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

Option C: Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint dislocation. Patient presents with neck pain and torticollis.

Option D: Holman-Miller sign or antral sign is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. It is a pathognomonic feature of angiofibroma.

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called_______.
questions.solution:
This suture technique is called mattress suture.

The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.

Other options :

B) The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end.

C) Continuous suture technique is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edges of the wound, this is performed continuously till the end is reached.

D) Interrupted suture technique is performed inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and crossing both the edge of the wound and the knot is tied.

questions.text: Barium study in a patient showed the Fleischner sign. The patient may be a case of _______
questions.solution:
The Fleischner sign on barium study is seen in Ileocecal TB. The thickening widely gaping ileaocaecal valve lips resulting in a patulous valve with narrowing of the terminal ileum is called the Fleischner sign. It is also called the inverted umbrella sign.

Signs of Tuberculosis intestine:

  • String sign
  • Gooseneck sign
  • Stierlein sign
  • Fleishner sign
  • Pulled up cecum

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Discoidal HDL is converted to HDL3 by the action of :
questions.solution:
Discoidal HDL is converted to HDL3 by the action of LCAT (Lecithin: Cholesterol Acyl Transferase)

LCAT converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL, thus converting discoidal HDL to HDL3 and then to HDL2. This is an important part of reverse cholesterol transport to the liver.

Other options

Also, these cholesterol esters are transferred from HDL to VLDL and LDL via CETP (cholesterol ester transfer protein) which are then taken up by receptors in the liver.

apo A-I is the activator of LCAT.

Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyses TAG in chylomicron and VLDL in the capillaries.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old sustained a crush injury. On examination he is found to have cool extremities and reduced pulses. Labs show the following findings: BUN- 84 Serum creatinine- 3.8 Urine Na-5 mEq/litre Urine osmolality - 700 mOsm/kg

What could be the possible cause of this patient's lab findings?
questions.solution:
Hypovolaemia is a possible cause for this patient's lab findings.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute kidney injury (AKI). AKI is defined as any of the following:

  • Increase in serum creatinine to ≥1.5 times baseline (50% higher), which is known or presumed to have occurred within the prior 7 days.
  • Increase in serum creatinine by ≥0.3 mg/dL from baseline within 48 hours.
  • Urine volume of <0.5 ml/kg/h for 6 hours.

AKI may have pre-renal, renal, or post-renal causes. This patient has a BUN/Creatinine ratio> 20 which is seen in prerenal AKI. Among the options listed, hypovolaemia is the only cause of prerenal AKI.

questions.text: What type of glands are seen in Fordyce spots?
questions.solution:
Fordyce spots are sebaceous glands without hair follicles and these sebaceous glands are an example of holocrine gland.

Glands have been classified into 3 types, which includes:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine (Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll) Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa Eg: Sweat glands on palms and solesFound everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

Related Pearl: Fordyce Spots

Fordyce spots/Fordyce granules:

  • The Fordyce spots are heterotopic sebaceous glands wherein the duct is connected directly to the overlying skin or mucosal surface unlike other sebum glands which open into the follicle.
  • They are called ectopic/free-lying sebaceous glands.
  • They occur commonly on the vermilion border of upper lip(m/c), buccal mucosa, skin over penile shaft and areolar of the breast.
  • They are commonly multiple and appear as symmetrical discrete yellow papules.
  • Fordyce spots on penis are called Tyson glands.
  • They are asymptomatic.
  • Treatment ladder
    • First line: Reassurance
    • Second line
      • Local destruction with superficial cautery or electrodessication
      • Topical trichloracetic acid

questions.text: Sinus which is not present in falx cerebri is ___________
questions.solution:
Falx cerebri does not contain occipital sinus.

The falx cerebri is a sickle-shaped dural fold separating the right and left cerebral hemispheres. It contains the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, and straight sinuses in it.

Occipital sinus is present in Falx cerebelli. Falx cerebelli separates the cerebellar hemispheres.

questions.text: All are true about Neutrophil extracellular Traps (NET) except ________
questions.solution:
NETs are mainly effective against bacteria and fungi (not viruses).

Neutrophilic extracellular traps are networks of extracellular fibres that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at the site of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

During the production of the NETs, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost leading to the death of neutrophils.

The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus.

They are detected in sepsis.

questions.text: In the OPD, you inform a patient that he has bladder cancer. However, he replies saying, "No, I cannot have cancer. I don't smoke or drink”. What is the type of defense mechanism exhibited by the patient?
questions.solution:
Denial is the defense mechanism seen in this patient. Denial is a refusal to accept external reality because it is too threatening.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A 10-year-old kid presents with antrochoanal polyp arising from the medial wall of the maxilla. Which of the following is the best management for the kid?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for antrochoanal polyp is functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

It has superseded earlier procedures such as simple polypectomy and Caldwell–Luc operation. However, in patients with a recurrent disease Caldwell–Luc operation may be required to excise the origin of the polyp.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest radiography image shows miliary tuberculosis.

It is the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, via hematogenous spread.

Classic miliary TB is defined as millet-like (mean, 2 mm; range, 1-5 mm) seeding of TB bacilli with uniform size and distribution in the lung, as seen on chest radiography. This particular sign is called the miliary shadow which is also seen in sarcoidosis and histoplasmosis.

Sputum-smear microscopy is negative in most cases.

Physical findings include hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy

Bronchoalveolar lavage and transbronchial biopsy are used to provide bacteriologic confirmation

Related Pearl: Causes of miliary shadow in Chest X-ray

Miliary shadow refers to innumerable, small (1-4 mm) pulmonary nodules scattered throughout the lungs. It is seen in - 

  • Miliary tuberculosis
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Pneumoconiosis – coal workers pneumoconiosis and silicosis
  • Healed varicella
  • Long-standing MS – can lead to pulmonary hemosiderosis
  • Alveolar microlithiasis
  • Papillary and medullary Ca thyroid

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and constipation. Upon examination, the physician notes a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: This condition is caused by an exotoxin
The toxin type G is associated with sudden death
Detection of antitoxin can aid in diagnosis
The toxin causes spastic paralysis by blocking the release of Acetylcholine

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of infant botulism. Statement 4 is the false statement since the toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine.

Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, and is of three types:

  • Foodborne botulism
  • Infant botulism
  • Wound botulism

Infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome): It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months; It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxin. The characteristic clinical history is paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weak, altered cry, and loss of head control. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxin or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

Other options:

  • Clostridium botulinum produces a powerful exotoxin that is responsible for its pathogenicity.
  • The toxin type G is associated with sudden death.
  • A retrospective diagnosis can be made by detection of antitoxin in the serum but it may not be seen in all cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is a tenderness in the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.solution:
The above image shown is hematoma of the auricle. It does not resolve spontaneously. It is also known as a perichondrial hematoma and can lead to cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear which is a deformity of the ear caused by repeated trauma. It is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium known as perichondrial space. It is commonly seen in boxers, wrestlers and rugby players due to blunt trauma.

Treatment:

  All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics. Aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. When aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done.

questions.text: Medullary thyroid cancer secretes all of the following except?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice in this patient.

This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

SBP is a common and severe complication of ascites characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source.

The most common organisms are Escherichia coli and other gut bacteria.

The diagnosis of SBP is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

The first line of empiric treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin because the majority of cases are caused by aerobic gram-negative microbes such as E. coli, with cefotaxime being the most commonly used antibiotic.

In patients who have had an episode(s) of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: A gynaecologist wants to study the association between vaginal adenocarcinoma and in-utero DES (Diethylstilbestrol) exposure. She selects subjects who have vaginal adenocarcinoma and subjects who do not and administers a questionnaire to assess DES exposure. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
In a case-control study, the study begins from the outcome and goes retrospectively to find out the exposure among the cases and controls.

Other Options:

Option A: A cross-sectional study looks at data from a population at a single point in time.

Option B: A cohort study begins with exposure and follows patients prospectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Meckel’s diverticulum?

choices.text: It is located within 2 inches from the ileocecal valve
It has 3 types of heterotopic mucosa
It is approximately 2 feet in length

questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum containing all layers of the intestine. Diverticula that contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. Others are false diverticula.

Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)(option B)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve (option A)
    • approximately 2 inches in length (option D)
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleeds in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

questions.text: A patient with a history of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart. On examination, it is noticed that her weight for height is 20 per cent below of what is expected. Which of the following needs to be done?

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.solution:
Patients with weight for height 20 per cent below of what is expected, should be considered for hospitalization.

Dur­ing a hospitalized treatment program

  • Patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
  • Daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
  • If vomiting occurs, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.

Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.

Psychotherapy:

  • Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
  • Dynamic Psychotherapy
  • Family Therapy

Pharmacotherapy:

Pharmacological studies have not yet identified any medica­tion that yields a definitive improvement of the core symptoms of anorexia nervosa. Some reports support the use of

  • Cypro­heptadine
  • Amitriptyline
  • Clomipramine
  • Pimozide
  • Chlorproma­zine
  • Fluoxetine

questions.text: The axons of the ganglion cells from the nasal retina of the right eye project to the _________

choices.text: Layers 2,3, and 5 of the right lateral geniculate body
Layers 1,4, and 6 of the left lateral geniculate body
Layers 2,3, and 5 of the left lateral geniculate body
Layers 1,4, and 6 of the right lateral geniculate body

questions.solution:
The axons of the ganglion cells from the nasal retina of the right eye project to the layers 1,4, and 6 of the left lateral geniculate body.

The axons of the retinal ganglion cells project a detailed spatial representation of the retina on the lateral geniculate body. Each lateral geniculate body has six well-defined layers numbered from 1 to 6. Of these layers,

  • Layers 1,4, and 6 receive the projections of the axons from the nasal retina of the contralateral eye (crossed fibres)
  • Layers 2,3, and 5 receive the projections of the axons from the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye (uncrossed fibres)

questions.text: An adult sustained a burn injury involving the bilateral lower limbs, genitalia, and one palm space burn area in the chest. What is the percentage of total burns surface area?
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 38% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

In this case, the estimation of % total burns surface area is as follows.

  • Right lower limb (18%) + Left lower limb (18%) = 36%
  • Genitalia = 1%
  • One palm space are in the chest =1%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 36 + 1 + 1 = 38%

 

Estimation of burns surface area:

Wallace’s rule of nine: It is used to calculate the percentage of burn.

It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. The values are modified in the pediatric age group owing to the difference in the body surface area in adults and children.

For calculating the % surface area affected by small burns or patches of burns, a piece of clean paper is cut into the size of the patient's whole hand. This corresponds to 1% of total burns surface area (TBSA). The area affected by small burns is matched using this cut paper.

Note: Lund and Browder's chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected.

Fluid resuscitation is done based on the estimated burns surface area using the Wallace rule. The fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 4ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours after the burn injury, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

questions.text: A factory worker at a plastic pipe factory presented with weight loss and abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for the last 6 months. He had hepatomegaly. CT abdomen revealed that most of the liver was infiltrated by contrast-enhanced mass and the presence of thorium was detected. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the factory worker with upper quadrant abdominal pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and the CT inference suggest angiosarcoma of the liver.

Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver shows greyish-white lesions, with multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces. CT is the preferred investigation and it reveals infiltrating contrast-enhanced mass diffusely spread over the liver. Thorium is picked up in the CT due to the presence of heterogeneously enhanced attenuation in the liver, perihepatic area, and spleen.

Option A: Cavernous hemangiomas appear as red-blue, soft nodules, usually less than 2 cm in diameter. Their clinical significance is that they might be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for metastatic tumors. Peripheral filling at the delayed phase of the contrast administration is a typical finding in this condition as the tumor is more in the periphery of the liver.

Option B: Metastatic tumor of the liver can be differentiated from primary HCC on a CECT. There is no enhancement or enhancement less than the surrounding liver following contrast.

Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a delayed arterial filling phase and washes out rapidly in a CECT. It also shows a wedge-shaped perfusion abnormality in the CT due to arterioportal shunts.

  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A G2P1 lady with 37 weeks of gestation is in active labor. You assist your labor room resident in giving a pudendal block. The resident explains that you have to approach the nerve by identifying a particular surface landmark. The landmark for this nerve block is:
questions.solution:
The ischial spine is the landmark for the pudendal nerve block. This is because the pudendal nerve is accessible here as it passes below the sacrospinous ligament at the level of attachment of the ligament to the ischial spine.

Sensory nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve arise from S2, S3, and S4 nerves. Pudendal nerve blocks in combination with local anesthetic are used to provide perineal anesthesia during the second stage of labor.

Here, a special needle (Koback)  and a guide (Iowa trumpet) are used. The needle is placed transvaginally underneath the ischial spine on each side and is advanced 1 to 1.5 cm through the sacrospinous ligament. 10 mL of 1% lidocaine or 2% chloroprocaine is used for the procedure.

The pudendal nerve block can be used for:

  • Analgesia during the second stage of labor. A pudendal block is used when there are contraindications to epidural/ spinal anesthesia or if there is a need for low vaginal and perineal anesthesia.
  • Episiotomy repair
  • Minor procedures of the lower vagina and perineum.
  • Instrumental delivery.

The complications of the procedure are accidental intravascular injection, retro-psoas abscess, subgluteal abscess, and retroperitoneal hematoma.

Also, note that the pudendal block does not impact the cervix or upper vagina and is ineffective for pain relief associated with uterine manipulation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought to the hospital with the following skin lesions on both the legs as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year-old child with the lesions shown in the given image in a string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign is characteristic of linear IgA disease. The main target antigens seen in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2.

Linear IgA disease/chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) is an immunobullous disease of childhood that clinically can present as an annular arrangement of vesicles. It arises more abruptly in children compared to adults. It has a bimodal onset, below the age of 5 years and between the age of 60 - 65 years.

Clinical features include:

  • Mucous membrane lesions like oral erosions and ulcers are commonly seen. Nasal crusting and genital lesions may also occur.
  • Tense blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, resembling a crown/cluster of jewels or a string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and perineum.
  • In adults, the distribution is over the extensors and the trunk.

Note: The string of pearls or cluster of jewels sign, is characteristic of linear IgA disease but not pathognomic to this disease. 

The image below shows a string of pearls appearance in the Linear IgA disease.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Infections
  • Trauma
  • Vaccination
  • UV radiation exposure
  • Drugs like:
    • Vancomycin
    • Penicillin
    • NSAIDs

The main target antigens in this disease are BP180 and BPAg2 much more than BP230 or BPAg1.The mechanism of blister formation is due to the subepidermal splitting and neutrophilic infiltrate in the papillary dermis forming microabscesses. 

The image given below shows subepidermal blister formation and neutrophils infiltrate in the papillary dermis.

The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Management involves:

  • First line:
    • Dapsone
    • Topical steroids with or without prednisolone
  • Second line:
    • Sulfa drugs like Sulfapyridine/ sulphamethoxypyridazine being alternatives for dapsone.
    • Anti‐inflammatory antibiotics like oxytetracycline, doxycycline with or without nicotinamide
  • Third line:
    • Mycophenolate
    • IVIG
    • Immunoadsorption

questions.text: A 43-year-old female presents with continuous vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks starting with the onset of menses. On examination the uterus is bulky. The urine pregnancy test is negative. USG shows an endometrial thickness of 24mm. Endometrial biopsy shows cystic glandular hyperplasia. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?

choices.text: It is a specialized form of anovulatory AUB
It might be preceded by a period of amenorrhea

questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica. Secretory endometrium is not seen in metropathia haemorrhagica.

Metropathia haemorrhagica, a specialized form of anovulatory AUB, is seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. As the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone, and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

The uterus is slightly bulky, uniformly enlarged and the uterine wall shows a mild degree of myohyperplasia, measuring up to 2.5 cm. The endometrium is thick, polypoidal, and thin slender polyps project into the uterine cavity. The endometrium shows characteristic cystic glandular hyperplasia, which appears as a swiss cheese pattern.

Corpus luteum is absent and one or both ovaries may contain a cyst, not larger than 5 cm.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with deafness, tinnitus, and bleeding from the ear. On examination, reddish mass is seen behind an intact tympanic membrane which blanches on the pressure with the pneumatic speculum. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The Brown’s sign is elicited by otoscopy
The rising sun sign  is seen on otoscopy

questions.solution:
This is a case of a glomus tumour.  The cell of origin in the glomus tumour is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Other options:

Option A: The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumour. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

Option B: Brown sign (Pulsation sign) is positive. When ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumour pulsates vigorously and then blanches. The reverse happens with the release of pressure.

Option C: Otoscopy shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane. The rising sun appearance is seen when the tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient developed the following changes in the hand. Which of the following does not cause the following findings?
questions.solution:
A petroleum fire is going to cause a burn, not a scald.

A ‘scald’ refers to tissue damage from hot liquids, usually water.  Other hot fluids include oils, molten rubber, other liquid chemicals, and steam.

Scalds are sharply demarcated lesions with reddening, desquamation, and blistering. When tipped or splashed, the hot liquid runs under gravity so that trickle patterns may be seen.

questions.text: An adventurous sea diver wanted to explore more depths than usual. After a few minutes of attaining greater depths, he feels intoxicated. Which of the following statement is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Increased solubility of nitrogen in nerve cell
Nitrogen is 5 times more soluble in fat compared to water

questions.solution:
The clinical condition is suggestive of nitrogen narcosis. Nitrogen will not inhibit the dismutase enzyme.

Nitrogen is 5 times more soluble in fat compared to water. As a result, nitrogen dissolves in the fatty substances in neuronal membranes, and because of its physical effect on altering ionic conductance through the membranes, it reduces neuronal excitability and produces the narcotic effect.

According to Dalton’s law, nitrogen contributes the maximum to barometric pressure, and hence the amount of nitrogen entering alveoli increases.

Nitrogen narcosis has characteristics similar to those of alcohol intoxication, and for this reason, it has frequently been called raptures of the depths.

questions.text: Which of these scenarios describes an epidemic?

choices.text: 420 cases of dengue in Mysore this week, compared to 410 cases last week
560 cases of avian flu in Tokyo this week, compared to 30 last week
1 case of meningococcal meningitis in Wuhan this week, compared to 0 last week
100000 cases of cholera in the US and UK this week, compared to 17 last week

questions.solution:
Epidemic - Occurrence of disease in excess of expected frequency. Ex: 560 cases this week, compared to 30 last week.  (Option b)

Pandemic - Epidemic affecting a large population over a large geographical area (Option d)

Endemic - A regularly occurring disease in a population in expected frequency without any importation from outside. (Option a)

Sporadic - Scattered cases of infection without relation temporally/spatially. Irregularly occurring disease. (Option c)

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not a component of Mickey mouse sign in B mode duplex scan?
questions.solution:
The External iliac artery is not a component of the Mickey mouse sign in B mode duplex scan of the lower limb.

Mickey mouse sign is seen in the B mode duplex scan in the groin region.

Mickey mouse sign is due to the great saphenous vein, common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and saphenofemoral junction.

questions.text: In disaster management, which step occurs immediately after response?
questions.solution: The correct sequence of steps is disaster impact – response – rehabilitation – prevention/mitigation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old father develops itchy, eczematous, exudative, papulopustular lesions along with excoriations for 2 weeks. His 9-month-old child also develops similar lesions. However, superficial burrows are seen in the father but not in his child. Which of the following sites will be spared for the father but involved in the child?
questions.solution:
The lesions described and the findings of superficial burrows indicate scabies in the father. Scabies in adults differ from that of infants in that it spares the face, scalp, palm and soles.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. Scabies are transmitted by close contact from human to human or from pet animals to humans. Thus, there are usually several cases in the same household.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital in active labor. She gives a history of being HIV positive and is on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks. She delivers a healthy male baby of 2.6kg. According to the NACO guidelines, at what dose and duration nevirapine has to be given to the infant?
questions.solution:
Nevirapine prophylaxis has to be given for a minimum period of 12 weeks at a dose of 15mg OD, as the mother has taken ART for less than 4 weeks in the antenatal period and the infant is to be breastfed.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker patient is brought to the hospital due to pain and weakness in the left arm for the past week. He also complains of left-sided chest pain for the last 3 weeks along with malaise, fever and weight loss for the past month. Which of the following tests is more preferred to point to the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features of left-sided chest pain, fever, weight loss, and malaise combined with pain and weakness of the left arm are suggestive of a Pancoast tumor. Chest CT is more preferred along with PET scan. MRI can be supplemented to aid the diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or postobstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread of the tumor can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man met with a road traffic accident. What will be the nature of breathing if his brainstem is transected at the mid-pontine level with bilateral vagus being spared?
questions.solution:
The transection of the brainstem at the mid-pontine level with bilateral vagal sparing causes the continuation of regular breathing.

The respiration is regulated by the pneumotaxic centre and the apneustic centre, which are located in the pons. At mid pontine level lesion, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated.

questions.text: A  primigravida patient was admitted with complaints of epigastric pain, headache, and visual symptoms. Her blood pressure was 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria 3+ was present. Her gestational age is 36 weeks. It was decided to start Pritchard's regimen, What is the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate?
questions.solution:
The woman has developed preeclampsia which is evident by the given clinical scenario and findings and according to Pritchard's regimen, the maintenance dose of magnesium sulfate is 5g intramuscularly, 4 hourly in alternate buttocks.

Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder with unknown aetiology and characterised by blood pressure of >140/90 mm hg or proteinuria in a woman who was previous normotensive and non-proteinuric. 

Magnesium sulfate regimens in the management of pre-eclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4-6 g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

It is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery whichever is later.

Repeat injections of magnesium sulfate are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 mL/h
  • Respiratory rate > 12/minute
The therapeutic level of serum magnesium is 4–7 mEq/L.

 Magnesium toxicity can be suspected if there is 

  1. Loss of deep tendon reflexes at serum Mg > 7 mEq/L
  2. Respiratory depression at serum Mg > 10 mEq/L and 
  3. Cardiac arrest at serum Mg > 25 mEq/L.

Magnesium toxicity is managed by stopping magnesium therapy after which serum magnesium and creatinine levels are estimated. Then, intravenous calcium gluconate 10 ml is injected.

Magnesium sulfate is also used for the management of torsades de pointes in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not used for induced hypotension during surgery?
questions.solution:
Mephentermine is an alpha adrenergic agonist and not used as an agent for induced hypotension during surgery.

It is used to treat hypotension and maintain blood pressure that is adequate for CNS perfusion. This may be advantageous in patients with hypotension due to failure of the sympathetic nervous system (e.g., after spinal anesthesia or injury). However, in patients with other forms of shock, such as cardiogenic shock, reflex vasoconstriction generally is intense, and α receptor agonists may further compromise blood flow to organs such as the kidneys and gut and adversely increase the work of the heart.

Drugs used for controlled(induced hypotension):-

vasodilators:  nitroprusside, nitroglycerine, hydralazine

beta blockers: esmolol, fenoldopam, adenosine and alprostadil are new hypotensive drugs.

Related Pearl: Hypotensive Anesthesia

Defined as:

  • Reduction of the systolic blood pressure to 80-90 mmHg, or 
  • Reduction of mean arterial pressure (MAP) to 50-65 mmHg, or
  • Reduction of MAP to 30% of baseline.

Controlled hypotension has been used to reduce bleeding and the need for blood transfusions, and provide a satisfactory bloodless surgical field.

It has been indicated in Oro-maxillofacial surgery (mandibular osteotomy, facial repair), endoscopic sinus or middle ear microsurgery, spinal surgery and other neurosurgery (an aneurysm), major orthopedic surgery (hip or knee replacement, spinal), prostatectomy, cardiovascular surgery and liver transplant surgery.

Agents used successfully include inhalation anesthetics, sodium nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, trimethaphan camsilate, clonidine, phentolamine, beta blockers, remifentanil, and agents used in spinal anesthesia for orthopedic surgeries

Newer hypotensive drugs, such as fenoldopam, adenosine, and alprostadil, are currently being evaluated.

questions.text: What is the rectal pressure at which the normal healthy person loses his voluntary control over his bowel evacuation?
questions.solution:
When the rectal pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex:

Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg.
