questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.

  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents.
  • It allows better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Other Options:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is excreted through renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion; hence, in paediatric patients and patients with poor renal function this test is considered superior to DTPA scan.
  • The screening investigation used in renovascular hypertension is Captopril DTPA and gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Which of the following is the property of endothelin-I?
questions.solution:

They are produced by endothelial cells. They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion.

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

  • Platelet activation.
  • Inotropic effect.
  • Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Clonorchis sinensis?

choices.text: Liver imaging shows dilated biliary tract
The second intermediate host is crab

questions.solution:
The second intermediate host of Clonorchis sinensis is fish (and not crab).

Clonorchis sinensis or Chinese liver fluke causes clonorchiasis.

  • Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae).

The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.

The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs that are excreted in the faeces. Upon reaching freshwater the eggs are ingested by snails, which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (rediae) and then into many free-swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst to form metacercariae under the scales of certain freshwater fish (second intermediate host) which are then ingested by humans.

  • In humans, it infects the common bile duct and gallbladder. Liver imaging shows a dilated biliary tract.
  • It is a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

The life cycle of clonorchis sinensis.

questions.text: Which of the following options does not describe the following postmortem changes?
questions.solution:
Tattooing is not related to the above postmortem changes. The image shows suggillation.

 

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discolouration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  

Any pressure prevents the capillaries from filling, such as the collar band, wrist band, belts, wrinkles in the clothes, etc. and such areas remain free from colour and are seen as strips or bands called vibices.

questions.text: The structural similarity to which of the following makes Lipoprotein-a (Lp-a) a risk factor for CAD?
questions.solution:
The structural similarity to plasminogen makes lipoprotein-a a risk factor for CAD.

Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) that contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein a (apo a).

Apo-a is a structural analogue of plasminogen. It inhibits clot lysis, which makes it a risk factor for thrombosis and CAD. Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk, independent of total cholesterol or LDL levels

Note:

apolipoprotein-a causes atherosclerosis whereas apolipoprotein-A prevents atherosclerosis since it is the major apolipoprotein of HDL.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman often says that her nose is "too fat" and she looks ugly. Because of this, she has stopped going out with friends. She spends almost half a day staring at herself in the mirror despite her husband's reassuring efforts that she is beautiful. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of preoccupation about the appearance of her nose associated with performing compulsive acts, like checking in the mirror, is suggestive of body dysmorphic disorder.

Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) is one of the obsessive-compulsive spectrum disorders as per DSM-5 (diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders). It is characterised by impairing and distressing preoccupations about an imagined defect or overemphasis on a slight defect in one’s appearance. This causes significant emotional distress and impairment in the patient's functioning.

In response to their appearance concerns, individuals with BDD may perform compulsive acts like excessive grooming, and constantly checking in the mirror. Some patients also perform mental acts such as comparing their appearance to that of other people. They may avoid social gatherings which can range up to being housebound. 

Patients with BDD can be treated with serotonin-specific drugs such as clomipramine and fluoxetine. 

Other options:

Option A: Social anxiety disorder or social phobia specifically involves the fear of social situations. Patients with this disorder are usually scared of embarrassing themselves in social situations. 

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder or hypochondriasis is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation for ≥6 months with fears of having a serious disease. This is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Factitious disorder is an intentional attempt to produce, stimulate or aggravate an illness to gain medical attention. The primary intention is not financial gains or avoidance of duties here.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with fungal infection of the sinuses and periorbital region, with significant visual impairment, as shown below. Vascular involvement and thrombosis are seen in the biopsy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, and lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus oryza.

The agents of zygomycosis are angioinvasive. The major clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis. It results from the germination of the sporangiospores in the nasal passages of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels. This causes thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The disease progress to invade the paranasal sinuses, eyes, cranial bone, and brain. It damages blood vessels and nerves, thereby developing edema of the involved facial area, a bloody nasal exudate, and orbital cellulitis.

A culture of nasal discharge, tissue, or sputum will show broad hyphae with uneven thickness, irregular branching, and sparse septations.

Treatment includes aggressive surgical debridement, rapid administration of amphotericin B, and control of the underlying disease.

Other options:

Option A: Coccidioidomycosis primarily includes pulmonary infection. It is caused by Coccidioides immitis. A self-limited influenza-like fever may occur in some individuals. Disseminated disease is seen in less than 1% of the people

Option B: Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It presents as a pulmonary disease that resembles tuberculosis. Disseminated histoplasmosis involves infection of the reticuloendothelial system which manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia.

Option D: Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases that are caused by a number of Aspergillus species. It can either present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: Mcafee and Johnson's  management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at :

choices.text: Immediate termination irrespective of gestational age

questions.solution:
Mcafee and Johnson's expectant management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at 37 weeks.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health(Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk

         Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or

         Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses

  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: The fracture seen in the image given below is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fracture at the neck of 5th metacarpal which is known as Boxer's fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Bennett’s fracture-dislocation occurs at the base of the first metacarpal bone and is commonly due to punching.

Option B: Rolando fracture - intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Option C: Chauffeur fracture - fracture of the radial styloid process.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus includes:
questions.solution:
The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (Adam’s/Hakim’s triad):

  • Dementia
  • Ataxia (gait disturbance) or apractic
  • Urinary incontinence

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. Timely diagnosis and prompt intervention can lead to the reversal of symptoms in NPH.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim-Adams syndrome):

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • Adam’s / Hakim’s triad (as mentioned above)
  • Papilloedema is not seen.
  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures may appear propped open (so-called “boxcarring”), which can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy.
  • Treatment-  Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure

questions.text: The most common position of the appendix is denoted by:
questions.solution:
The labelling” A “ represents retrocecal position of the appendix, which is the most common position.

This is because the appendix develops during the descent of the colon in embryonic life.

The base of the appendix is fixed and, depending on the direction of the tip, the positions of the appendix are as follows:

  • Retro-caecal: 64%
  • Sub-caecal: 2%
  • Pelvic: 32%
  • Post-ileal: 0.5%
  • Pre-ileal: 1%

questions.text: Abnormal family dynamics, where one parent dominates over the other, is an etiological factor that is implicated in the development of schizophrenia. This theory is described as ______
questions.solution:
Abnormal family dynamics, where one parent dominates over the other, is described as marital skew.

Marital schism, marital skew, expressed emotions and double-bind refer to abnormalities of family dynamics.

They act as psychosocial stressors, hampering the adaptive capacity of the individual, thus contributing to the development of schizophrenia.

  • Marital schism - one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender.
  • Marital skew - a disharmonious situation where one parent dominates over the other.
  • Expressed emotions - parents or other caregivers may behave with overt criticism, hostility, or overinvolvement towards a person with schizophrenia, which further worsens the illness, as evidenced by increased rates of relapse.
  • Double bind - a hypothetical family in which children receive conflicting parental messages about their behaviour, attitudes, and feelings.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first germ layer that is formed and the cells it originates from respectively?
questions.solution:
Endoderm is the first germ layer to form and it is formed from epiblast cells.

Epiblast gives rise to all the 3 germ layers through the process of gastrulation.

After the formation of the primitive streak, the epiblast cells migrate towards the primitive streak. When they arrive at the primitive streak, these cells become flask-shaped, detach from the epiblast, and slip beneath the primitive streak. This inward movement is known as invagination.

Some of the invaginated epiblast cells displace the hypoblast to create the embryonic endoderm. Endoderm is the first germ layer to form. Some of the invaginated cells then start occupying the space between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm. Cells remaining in the epiblast then form the ectoderm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, who is a known case of cancer lung, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, combing hair.etc..Lab tests reveal an elevation in Creatinine Kinase and muscle biopsy reveals perimysial infiltrates and atrophy with CD4+ T cells. The following sign is seen. Name the sign.
questions.solution:
The clinical sign seen in the image is Gottron’s sign. Gottron’s sign is an erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.

This patient’s clinical features of lung cancer and proximal myopathy are suggestive of a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory disorder characterized by muscle weakness and skin lesions. It is commonly seen in the 50-60 year age group and affects proximal muscles more than distal muscles. Characteristic skin findings include:

  • Gottron's sign
  • Gottron's papules
  • Heliotrope rash
  • V sign
  • Shawl sign

It is commonly associated with internal malignancy.

Muscle biopsy is characteristic for perifasicular and perimysial inflammatory infiltrate and atrophy. Infiltrates consist of CD4+ T cells, B cells, and macrophages. Labs reveal elevated creatinine Kinase levels. Autoantibodies seen include Anti Mi2, Anti-NCP2, anti MDA5, and anti- Tlf1.

First-line treatment includes a high dose of corticosteroids. The response is usually good for therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Heberden's nodes are hard or bony swellings that can develop in the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) seen in osteoarthritis.

Option C: Russell's sign refers to calluses on the knuckles or back of the hand due to repeated self-induced vomiting over long periods of time.

Option D: Osler's nodes are painful, red, raised lesions found on the hands and feet. They are associated with a number of conditions, including infective endocarditis, and are caused by immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A 22 year old patient sustained a road traffic accident and was taken to the emergency department. The senior resident told the house surgeon to calculate the patient's Glasgow Coma Score . The house surgeon noted that the patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli,  flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. The house surgeon calculates the Glasgow Coma Score to be________.
questions.solution:
The GCS in this patient is 11.

Score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.

Score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to painful stimulus only.

Score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain.

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A woman brings her 72-year-old father to the OPD with a history of multiple episodes of him forgetting his way back home. She also says that her father is not able to make a sandwich for himself, unlike before. What is the expected histopathological feature in the patient's brain?

choices.text: Loss of dopaminergic neurons of substantia nigra pars

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette described here shows impaired memory and other executional functioning loss suggesting Alzheimer's disease. Neurofibrillary tangles on histopathological section confirm the diagnosis.

In the early stages, the memory loss may go unrecognized or be ascribed to benign forgetfulness of ageing.

In the middle stages, the patient is unable to work, is easily lost and confused, and requires daily supervision. Apraxia emerges, manifesting as trouble performing learned sequential motor tasks such as using utensils or appliances.

In the late stages, some persons remain ambulatory, wandering aimlessly.

Neurofibrillary tangles are seen in Alzheimer's disease.

Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular, hyperphosphorylated tau protein = insoluble cytoskeletal elements, the number of tangles correlates with degree of dementia.

Other options :

Option B : Loss of dopaminergic neurons of substantia nigra pars compacta is seen in Parkinson's.

Option C : Lewy bodies are seen in Parkinson's and Lewy body dementia.

Option D : Beta pleated sheets are seen in Prion disease. PrP (Prion protein) undergoes a conformational change from its normal α-helix (PrPc) to an abnormal β-pleated sheet (PrPsc) isoform and PrP becomes resistant to digestion with proteases.

questions.text: Which component of  Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) has the highest maximum score?
questions.solution:
Skeletal and soft tissue injury component of Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) has a maximum score of 4 which is the highest.

Components of Mangled Extremity Severity score :

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischaemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

Other options:

Option B: Limb ischaemia component has a maximum score of 3.

Option C: Shock component has a maximum score of 2.

Option D: Patient’s age component has a maximum score of 2.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient complains of diarrhoea, vomiting, and abdominal pain that was aggravated on ingestion of food for 1 week. Stool microscopy reveals strongyloidiasis, as evidenced by the larva seen in the image. Which of the following is wrong about the nematode causative of the disease?

choices.text: Infective form is the rhabditiform larva
Disseminated disease is seen in immunodeficient individuals

questions.solution:
The infective form of Strongyloides stercoralis is the filariform larva. The egg shown in the given figure is the egg of strongyloides containing the rhabditiform larva.

Transmission occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

The larvae molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the Rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

  • Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. Ovoviviparous – laying eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.
  • The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally.
  • Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in Immunodeficient individuals.

Larva currens:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who was diagnosed with HIV recently was started on HAART. Following subcutaneous injection of a certain antiviral drug, there was a reaction as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an injection site reaction, and it happens with enfuviritide.

Enfuviritide is a fusion inhibitor, and it is the only approved parenterally available antiretroviral drug.

NNRTI (efavirenz, delavirdine, nevirapine) causes hepatitis, drug rash.

NRTI’s (Zidovudine, lamivudine, emtricitabine) can cause peripheral neuropathy, pancreatitis, and gastrointestinal intolerance.

Protease inhibitors are known to cause gastrointestinal tolerance and fat redistribution.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The microscopic image of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following is not indicated in the treatment of infection with the following organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of generalized muscle spasms following a puncture wound with the given image showing Clostridium tetani suggests a diagnosis of tetanus. Hyperbaric oxygen is not indicated in the treatment of tetanus. 

The image shows slender, gram-positive bacilli with terminal spores that are spherical, bulging, and have a drumstick appearance, typical of Clostridium tetani. It is the causative agent of tetanus.

The treatment of tetanus involves cleaning and debridement of necrotic material in the wound. Metronidazole (400 mg rectally or 500 mg IV every 6 h for 7 days) is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin and prevent its uptake into the nervous system. Two preparations are available- human tetanus immune globulin (TIG) and equine antitoxin. TIG is the preparation of choice, as there is a lower chance of anaphylaxis. A single IM dose (500–5000 IU) is given, with a portion injected around the wound.

Clostridium tetani secrete 2 types of toxins, namely, tetanolysin and tetanospasmin. Of these, tetanospasmin has been implicated in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

Tetanospasmin acts pre-synaptically and specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters. This abolition of spinal inhibition causes the uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated everywhere in the central nervous system. This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultaneous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated in gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Principal bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Hyparterial bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein
Principal bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Eparterial bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein
Eparterial bronchus, Pulmonary artery, Principal bronchus, Inferior pulmonary vein

  • Superior lobar (Eparterial) bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal (Hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Mnemonic: BABV

The sequence of structures at the left hilum superior to inferior is:

  • Principal (Hyparterial) bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Mneumonic: ABV

questions.text: Intracranial hemorrhage that results from venous bleeding is
questions.solution:
Subdural hemorrhage results from venous bleeding.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A study shows a weak inverse correlation between vitamin intake and cancer. What is the probable correlation coefficient (r) in this study?
questions.solution:
A weakly inverse or negative correlation means r is negative and closer to 0, hence r= -0.2 is the most appropriate option.

The correlation coefficient (r) helps us find out whether there is a significant association or not between two variables. r tends to lie between - 1.0 and + 1.0.

  • If r is near + 1, it indicates a strong positive association i.e., when one variable increases the other variable also increases. (Option A)
  • A value near - 1 indicates a strong negative association i.e. when one variable increases the other decreases. (Option D)
  • If r = 0, it indicates there is no association between x and y.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the criteria used in diagnosing fat embolism syndrome?
questions.solution:
Increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (not decreased erythrocyte sedimentation rate ) is a criterion for the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome. Gurd's criteria is used to diagnose fat embolism syndrome.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which among the following nerve injury causes her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.

Other options-

Option A- The peroneal nerve can get compressed under the flexed knee during prolonged lithotomy positioning during labor. It can also occur when the patient's knees are resting against a firm surface like the hospital bed rails or stirrups during labor.

Options B and C- The iliohypogastric nerve and ilioinguinal nerve are most commonly injured during cesarean section.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the operations of the midday meal programme?

choices.text: Supplements 1/3rd of protein and 1/2 of calorie requirements
The mid-day meal is not a substitute for home meal
The menu should remain constant to ensure adequate nutrition
It is not a part of the Minimum Needs Programme

questions.solution:
The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.

Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) programme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least ½ of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of total daily energy requirement to children in schools.

The Midday meal scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Principles of the MDM are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.
  • The cost of meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meal should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, for as far as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, tremor, bilateral exophthalmos, and a mass in the anterior neck. Which of the following cutaneous feature is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the above clinical history the patient has hyperthyroidism, and palmar erythema is seen in hyperthyroidism.

Cutaneous features of Hyperthyroidism

  • Facial and Palmar Erythema: Flushing of the face and hands
  • Smooth, moist, and warm skin
  • Fine, soft, and thinned scalp hair
  • Distorted and overgrown nails (thyroid acropachy) that may lift off the nail bed (onycholysis)
  • Generalized Pruritis
  • Urticaria

Graves disease may also cause thyroid dermopathy resulting in pretibial myxoedema and exophthalmos, which are associated with the presence of thyroid antibodies.

Cutaneous features of Hypothyroidism:

  • Cold peripheries with pale and dry coarse skin
  • Aurantiasis cutis: A yellowish hue to the skin secondary to Beta-carotene accumulations
  • Sparse and brittle hair
  • Sign of Hertoghe: loss of hair in the outer third of eyebrows
  • Slow growing, ridged, and brittle
  • Myxoedema, resulting in puffy face, eyelids, hands, and feet
  • Delayed wound healing

questions.text: A patient complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most suitable treatment for this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal-shaped cystine stones. Hence the best suitable treatment for this patient with cystine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cystine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula, or distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stones, and calcium oxalate stones.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL include infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. ESWL is contraindicated in obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note: Stone fragments collected in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about surfactant.

choices.text: Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio of ≥1 is considered normal.
Shake test is used to assess the presence of surfactant.

questions.solution:
Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio of ≥2 is considered normal (not ≥1).

Surfactant acts by reducing the surface tension of water. It is produced by type 2 pneumocytes.

Components of surfactant:

  • Phospholipid - Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)/ dipalmitoyl lecithin is the major component. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol - minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Clinical relevance:

  • Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:
    • Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio, i.e. L/S ratio of ≥2 is considered normal.
    • Shake test/ Bubble test/ Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
    • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has an absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF, which is involved in the clearance of surfactant

questions.text: A middle-aged male who is drowsy is brought to the ER, by the police. On examination, he speaks inappropriately, provides different histories to intern, nurse, police. Imaging shows atrophic mammillary bodies. Labs show methylmalonic acid levels to be raised and folate deficiency. Which of the following would you use to treat him?

choices.text: IVF followed by thiamine followed by glucose
Thiamine followed by IVF followed by glucose

questions.solution:
Thiamine followed by glucose should be used to treat the patient to prevent the development of Wernicke encephalopathy. 

The features in the abovesaid clinical scenario such as drowsy state, incoherent and inappropriate speech, atrophic mamillary bodies (typically seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome), vitamin B12 deficiency (as given by increased methyl malonate levels), and folate deficiency point towards various complications of chronic alcoholism

Thiamine deficiency causes impaired glucose breakdown. Administration of glucose will worsen the patient condition.

Thiamine is required for glucose breakdown and it is required for the following enzymes:

  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Transketolase

Thiamine deficiency can be diagnosed by a decrease in RBC transketolase

questions.text: A child presents with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia. X-Ray of femur showed Erlen Mayer flask deformity. Bone marrow shows cells with crumpled tissue paper appearance. Which of the following is accumulated in the cells?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher’s disease. Glucocerebroside (glucosylceramide) is getting accumulated in the cells.

Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase). It is characterized by the following clinical features:

  • Painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Hypersplenism and pancytopenia
  • Bleeding tendencies
  • Bone pain
  • Osteoporosis, pathological fractures, Erlenmeyer flask deformity
  • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze palsy (seen in type 3)

Gaucher's cells - These are formed as a result of the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes. The cells have a fibrillary cytoplasm and give a crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Treatment:

  • Enzyme replacement therapy is available for type 1 disease in the form of:
    • Human recombinant acid β-glucosidase (Imiglucerase/ Velaglucerase alfa)
    • Taliglucerase alfa

Note: Neurological involvement is not seen in type 1 Gaucher's disease.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a swelling over the tibia which is gradually progressing in size and associated with pain for 8 months. An x-ray shows a dense lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin. What’s the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis arrived from the above-given clinical scenario is Brodie’s abscess.

Brodie abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

The above X-ray shows the dense sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction in the upper end of the tibia.

All the given conditions may present a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess Children, adolescents A lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents, and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years

A lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction, 

soap bubble appearance
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma cannot be the diagnosis as it is unlikely to occur in a 12-year-old and X-ray findings would show a typical soap bubble appearance.

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a rapidly growing malignant tumor. It is unlikely to have a gradually progressing course which is more suggestive of a subacute condition like Brodie's abscess.

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is unlikely to occur in the upper tibia as it is a diaphyseal tumor.

questions.text: The following image shows a deformity as a result of a fracture. Which of the following is false regarding the fracture under discussion?

choices.text: The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained
More commonly leads to cubitus valgus
Inability to do OK sign with fingers maybe seen

questions.solution:
The above image shows gunstock deformity which is commonly due to malunion following the supracondylar fracture.  Supracondylar fracture more commonly leads to cubitus varus ( not cubitus valgus.).

Other options:

Option A: The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks. The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon.

Option C: Posterior displacement is more common in supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Option D:   The patient is asked to perform an OK sign by touching the tips of the index finger and the thumb. Normally, the patient can flex the distal phalanges and a nice O-shape is produced (right side). Supracondylar fracture of the humerus commonly leads to anterior interosseous nerve injury (left side), where the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus are weak. The patient is unable to perform the OK sign. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented to the OPD with greenish discharge from her nipple. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Greenish discharge from the breast is usually caused by duct ectasia.

 Duct ectasia (periductal mastitis) involves dilatation of multiple ducts, which is often associated with periductal inflammation.

  • Most common age group affected: above 50 years 
  • Most common presenting feature: nipple discharge
  • Most common discharge in duct ectasia: serous discharge

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. It is associated with smoking. The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green coloured secretions. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.  If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

Other options:

Option A:  Intraductal papilloma is associated with blood stained discharge.

Option B: Fibrocystic disease is associated with serous discharge.

Option C:  Paget’s disease is characterized clinically by nipple erythema and irritation with associated pruritus and may progress to crusting and ulceration.

questions.text: A 40 year old male comes to OPD with a chronic history of  deformity of penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection. On examination there were palpable penile plaques. What is the surgical procedure commonly employed to correct this penile deformity?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure. This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

Other options:

Options A and B: Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option D: Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 36 weeks gestation, presents with palpitations, protrusion of the eyeball, and heat intolerance. On blood investigations, it was found that she had increased T3 and T4 levels and decreased TSH levels.  Which of the following should be the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is thyrotoxicosis. As she is in her third trimester, the drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis is methimazole.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy has been summarized in the table below.

Trimester Treatment options
First trimester

Propylthiouracil
Second trimester Methimazole (preferred)
Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester Methimazole

Thyrotoxicosis during pregnancy is usually controlled by thioamide drugs. Propylthiouracil was preferred previously because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole. However, since it has a higher risk of causing propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy, methimazole is prescribed according to guidelines in the second trimester and third trimesters. Methimazole is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy. 

Other options:

Option B: Subtotal thyroidectomy is done once the hyperthyroidism is medically controlled. It is usually avoided during pregnancy, however, may be done in some cases in the second trimester where it can't be controlled via medication.

Option D: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnant women as it may cause fetal thyroid gland destruction.

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OP with painful genital ulcers. Gram staining revealed gram-negative coccobacilli as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a suitable culture medium?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painful genital ulcer with gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in parallel chains is suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the suitable culture medium of Haemophilus ducreyi.

Chancroid or soft sore is a venereal disease characterized by tender non-indurated irregular ulcers on the genitalia. This infection remains localized, spreading only to the regional lymph nodes which are enlarged and painful. The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'rail road track' appearance.

On chocolate agar, enriched with IsoVitaleX and fetal calf serum, and containing vancomycin as a selective agent, H.ducreyi forms small, grey translucent colonies after incubation at 35°C under 10% CO and 2 high humidity in 2-8 days.

H.ducreyi requires X factor, but not V factor for growth. H.influenzae requires X and V factor for growth.

Note: Fish in-stream appearance is seen in Vibrio cholera.

questions.text: 50-year-old patient who is on oral hypoglycemic drugs for diabetes presented to the skin opd with oval, dull‐red papules measuring 0.5–1 cm in diameter over the shin as shown below. These lesions are due to ____
questions.solution:
The lesion described in the above case is characteristic of Diabetic Dermopathy, Which is also known as Binkley spots. The phrase diabetic dermopathy was coined by Binkley in 1965.

It is characterized by asymptomatic, oval, dull‐red papules 0.5–1 cm in diameter evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and atrophic brown scars.

Note :

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder seen in young women characterized by atrophic centers and central ulceration.

Diabetic scleredema patients present with non‐pitting swelling and induration of the upper part of the body caused by a thickened dermis and deposition of mucin.

questions.text: What is the level of obstruction of eccrine glands in the most common type of miliaria seen over the trunk in the hospitalized patient?
questions.solution:
Miliaria Rubra is common on the trunk in hospitalized patients. In miliaria rubra, the obstruction is seen in the Malpighian Layer.

Patients with miliaria rubra develop typical lesions over the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A 25-year-old rape victim was brought by the lady constable to the gynaecologist for examination. Which of the following tests need to be performed on her vaginal sample to identify it as semen?

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

questions.text: Which enzyme is involved in cataract formation in a patient with diabetes?
questions.solution:
Aldose reductase is the enzyme involved in cataract formation in a diabetic patient.

The polyol pathway has been implicated in the formation of diabetic cataracts. This pathway results in the production of fructose from glucose and, sorbitol is formed as an intermediate. Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. 

Diabetics have increased glucose levels in the lens, peripheral nerves, and renal glomeruli which are not insulin sensitive. This increases the activity of aldose reductase in these tissues. The sorbitol so formed accumulates in the lens leading to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

Options B and C are enzymes of galactose metabolism. Classical galactosemia is caused by deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).  Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain. Galactokinase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of galactose to galactose 1-phosphate. Only cataract is seen in the deficiency of this enzyme because galactose-1-phosphate is not formed. Hence no toxic effects of this compound are manifested. 

Option D:  Aldolase B is the enzyme that cleaves fructose-1-phosphate in fructose metabolism. A deficiency of this causes hereditary fructose intolerance.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman can recognize the voices of their college friends while talking over the mobile phone. But she finds it difficult to recognize them, by seeing their faces in the college. Which lobe could the lesion be in this case?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of prosopagnosia, which occurs due to the lesions of the inferior temporal lobe.

Prosopagnosia is an inability to recognize faces. Patients with this abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. How­ever, they cannot identify familiar people by seeing their faces. 

In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible.

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: An epidemiologist notes that the incidence of a condition is increasing. What does this most likely imply?

choices.text: Current programs to control the disease are effective
Reporting of the disease has increased
The causative agent has not shown any mutations
The environment has remained the same

questions.solution:
An increase in incidence could be due to increased reporting of the disease and hence cases that could have been missed earlier are now being counted.

An increase in incidence might indicate failure or ineffectiveness of the current control programs and suggest the need for a new disease control or preventive program.  A change or fluctuation in the incidence of disease may also mean a change in the etiology of disease, e.g., change in the agent, host, and environmental characteristics.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes with a history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability. The ultrasound image of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of amenorrhea, vomiting, and easy fatigability along with ultrasound findings of double decidual sign points to the diagnosis of normal pregnancy.

This sign can be seen in first-trimester transvaginal sonograms. In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that are - the outer decidua parietalis and the inner decidua capsularis. The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac. The presence of the yolk sac confirms the intrauterine location of the pregnancy. It usually appears by the 5th week.

Another indicator of early intrauterine pregnancy is the intradecidual sign. It is seen as an anechoic center surrounded by a single echogenic rim.

Cardiac motion is usually seen after the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon inadvertently cut an anomalous tortuous structure near the origin of the cystic duct. This leads to the obscuration of the operating field due to blood. What anomalous tortuous structure did the surgeon inadvertently cut?
questions.solution: The tortuous hepatic artery is the anomalous structure which the surgeon cut during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Tortuosity of the hepatic artery is an anomaly present in front of the origin of the cystic duct or right hepatic artery is tortuous and the cystic duct is short, this tortuosity is known as ‘caterpillar turn’ or ‘Moynihan’s hump’.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the gynecologist with complaints of severe itching in the vulva and foul-smelling, thin, green-colored vaginal discharge. Examination of the cervix shows the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image depicting colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix is seen in trichomoniasis.

Trichomoniasis is caused by the organism Trichomonas vaginalis. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. 

In women, diagnosis is usually confirmed by examination of wet mount microscopy and direct visualization. However, a culture, usually in Feinberg–Whittington medium, gives the most reliable results. 

Standard treatment is with a single oral dose of 2 grams of metronidazole or 2 grams of tinidazole. Metronidazole 500 mg given orally for seven days is also effective.

Colpitis Macularis or Strawberry Cervix(image below) appearance results from microscopic, punctate hemorrhages of the cervix. 

Other options:

Option 1: Chlamydial cervicitis is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Patients present with mucopurulent discharge or endocervical secretions, urethritis, dysuria, etc. On examination, the cervix may appear edematous and hyperemic.

The image below shows an inflamed cervix from chlamydia infection characterized by mucopurulent cervical discharge and erythema.

Option 3: Gonorrhea is a suppurative bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.The patient usually presents with profuse, odorless, non-irritant, white, or yellow vaginal discharge. They also have dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding. The patient might also present with proctitis.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale, a genital ulcer is caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. It is also known as donovanosis. It presents as painless nodules that develop into ulcerative lesions. The ulcer is highly vascular with a beefy red appearance and subcutaneous granulomas extend to form pseudobuboes.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Candidal vaginitis

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: You are a pediatrician evaluating a baby in the NICU. The mother had a history of fever and painful swellings in her neck at 9 weeks gestation. At that time, she had a maculopapular rash that spread from her face to her body and resolved in 3 days. Investigation had revealed Rubella IgM was positive in the mother.  Which of the following features is the baby most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The history of maternal fever, painful neck swellings, and a rash that subsided in 3 days, coupled with the IgM rubella is indicative of rubella infection of the mother. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur. 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

Note:

  • ASD: Ejection systolic murmur
  • VSD: Pansystolic murmur
  • Mitral stenosis: Mid diastolic murmur. 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A carrier who acquires the pathogen from another carrier is called:
questions.solution:
The paradoxical carrier is a carrier who acquired the pathogen from another carrier.

Incubatory carriers: Those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.

Convalescent carrier: Those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.

Healthy carrier: Those who had a subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from an overt disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with infertility underwent semen analysis. Results show a sperm concentration of 18 million/ml, pH- 7.5, and volume- 2 ml. No agglutination is seen. Morphology shows 10% normal forms and 20% motile sperms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given semen analysis point towards a diagnosis of asthenospermia as only 20% of the sperms are motile. Normally, 32% of sperm should be motile.

Other options:

Option A: Azoospermia - Absence of sperm in semen

Option C: Normospermia - Sperm concentration of > 15 million/ml

Option D: Oligospermia- Sperm concentration of < 15 million/ml 

Note: 

Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
