questions.text: Which of the following is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Multiple myeloma is not an AIDS-defining neoplasm.

The neoplasms considered to be AIDS-defining are:

  • Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix

In addition to these AIDS-defining neoplasms, there is also an increase in the incidence of other malignancies such as multiple myeloma, leukaemia, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, melanoma and carcinomas involving various organs.

Since the introduction of potent combination anti-retroviral therapy, the incidence of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and Kaposi’s sarcoma has declined.

questions.text: Which of the following is detected by TLR-3?
questions.solution:
Toll-like receptor (TLR) 3 binds to the viral RNA.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are transmembrane receptors that have an extracellular domain, which detects infecting pathogens.

  • TLR 1 - Tuberculosis
  • TLR 2 - Gram-positive bacteria
  • TLR 3 - Viral RNA
  • TLR 4 - Gram-negative bacteria
  • TLR 5 - Flagella
  • TLR 9 - Bacterial DNA, some herpes viruses, the malarial parasite

TLRs act through the NF-KB pathway and initiate inflammation.

questions.text: What are the cut-off values in 75gm oral glucose tolerance test for fasting, at 1 hr and 2 hrs after meals respectively?
questions.solution:
The cut-off values with a 75 g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) are 92,180 and 153 for fasting, at 1 hr and 2 hours after meals respectively.

According to WHO and ADA guidelines, the one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing for gestational diabetes mellitus by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

Diagnostic criteria or cut off values with a 75 g OGTT are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hour: 153 mg/dl

Two-step approach :

  • The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT).
  • Screen-positive patients go on to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which among the following sentences about collagen is false?

choices.text: Collagen has a triple helical structure, forming a right-handed superhelix
Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity to collagen
Enzyme lysyl oxidase is defective in Menkes disease which contains copper as a cofactor
Marfan syndrome is due to mutation in gene encoding collagen

questions.solution:
Among the following sentences about collagen, the false statement is (option D). Marfan syndrome is due to a mutation in the gene encoding fibrillin-1 (not collagen).

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It has a triple helical structure, forming a right-handed superhelix. A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, whose cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Collagen is arranged in a quarter-staggered arrangement and further stabilized by covalent cross-links.

Menke disease is a progressive neurodegenerative condition with an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance. It's caused by a defect in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired intestinal copper absorption and transport, resulting in low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels. This affects the cross-linking of collagen by lysyl oxidase, which requires copper as a cofactor, leading to defective connective tissue formation.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Which among the following causes maximum damage to biological tissues?
questions.solution:
Alpha radiation causes maximum damage to biological tissues.  

Alpha particles- consist of two neutrons and two protons and are identical to a helium nucleus. They interact strongly with matter, repeatedly collide with molecules, disrupting their chemistry, which is extremely damaging in living tissue.  

Beta particle- is an electron emitted by a nucleus. The damage caused by beta particles is much less severe than alpha radiation. Beta emitters are routinely used to deliver therapeutic radiation doses to tumours.  

Positron (beta+, β+ or e+)- is a particle similar to an electron except that it has a positive electric charge. Positron emitters are used in PET imaging.  

Gamma rays- are a form of electromagnetic radiation. They are emitted by an atomic nucleus in an excited state. Gamma rays are used in imaging.  

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

questions.text: Samter's triad consists of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Urticaria is not a component of Samter’s triad. Samter’s triad is a component of intrinsic asthma. It consists of nasal polyposis, intrinsic asthma, and aspirin sensitivity.

Idiosyncratic (or intrinsic) asthma is characterized by the following:

  • Negative skin tests to common inhalant allergens
  • Normal serum concentrations of IgE
  • Show later onset of disease (adult-onset asthma)
  • Commonly have concomitant nasal polyps and may be aspirin-sensitive
  • Usually have more severe, persistent asthma

questions.text: For a patient on allopurinol, what should be dose correction in oral 6- mercaptopurine?
questions.solution:
Oral dose of 6-mercaptopurine (6MP) requires reduction by 75% when administered with allopurinol.

6MP undergoes the first-pass metabolism by xanthine oxidase in the liver and intestine. Since allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, it causes elevated levels of 6-MP. Hence, the oral dose of 6MP needs to be reduced by 75 % if allopurinol is given.

In the case of intravenous administration, the dosage need not be changed as it escapes the first-pass metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding delirium?

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.solution:
Worsening of symptoms at night is known as sundowning which is seen in delirium.

Characteristic presentation of delirium:

  • Acute onset
  • Brief duration- Usually days to weeks
  • Fluctuating course- Unpredictable fluctuations in severity and other clinical manifestations
  • Sundowning- Worsening of symptoms at night
  • Rapid improvement- When the underlying cause is treated
  • Other characteristics: Asterexis, Carphologia (Picking movements on cover sheets and clothes)

There is a decline in the level of consciousness, which is considered the hallmark symptom of delirium.

Delirium is more commonly associated with visual hallucinations.

questions.solution:
